entry.title: How covid-19 is interrupting children’s education
entry.content:
CHILDREN USUALLY rejoice in a break from school, assuming it will be a chance to slack off. Not Ryu, a nine-year-old in Tokyo. As the new coronavirus spread across Japan, schools throughout the country closed on March 2nd. His parents have enforced a strict schedule every day. It includes Japanese, science and physical education. He does mathematics on his abacus every morning. On weekdays he is allowed to play in a park for 90 minutes. “I wish I could take him to the park more, but we have limited time as we work from home,” frets his mother, Fujimaki Natsuko.

Ryu is one of almost 1bn students around the world whose schooling has been interrupted as a result of covid-19 (see map). As The Economist went to press, just over 100 countries including China, Italy and South Korea had closed their schools, as had 43 states in America, as part of efforts to contain covid-19. Britain will close all schools on March 20th. Schools, where sticky-fingered children gather every day, sharing toys and sucking on pencils, are an obvious place for diseases to flourish. In 2013 Britain’s Health Protection Agency looked at flu outbreaks that coincided with school closures. It found that shutting them slowed the transmission of the virus, even if it also slowed the transmission of knowledge.

The data on whether school closures will curb covid-19 are limited. Children may not be the “main routes of transmission”, says Michael Head, who studies global health at the University of Southampton. And the economic, social and educational costs are heavy. On March 12th Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York, said there were “many, many reasons” not to close the city’s 1,800 schools (though on March 16th it did just that, shuttering America’s largest school system for at least four weeks). For all governments, deciding whether or not to close schools is a choice between two bad options.

A study in 2009 modelling the effects of closing all schools and formal day-care centres in America for a month put the cost at 0.1-0.3% of GDP. Some countries seem better prepared to deal with the economic impact. In China the nationwide closures came with government-mandated work-from-home policies and subsidies for companies to enable their employees to do so. But in Japan not all parents are entitled to work from home or to take paid sick leave. In Italy one-fifth of workers are self-employed and so do not qualify for sick pay. People in precarious work may lose their jobs altogether if they have to stay at home to look after children.

For poor children, schools may provide the most nutritious meal of the day. Around 26m children in American schools—roughly half of all students— qualify for free or reduced-price lunches. In New York City 22,000 children sleep in municipal shelters. Some school districts in New York are setting up pickup points so that the hard-up can still get free meals. Britain has said it will continue to provide those children who ordinarily get free school meals with food.

Officials must always take such costs into account. But in the middle of a pandemic there is an extra consideration. The study in 2009 estimated that, if schools are closed for a month, between 6% and 19% of key health-care workers would have to stay at home to take care of their offspring. Britain will keep schools running for vulnerable children and those whose parents are key workers.

For most parents, however, the immediate worry is how prolonged school closures will affect their children’s education. Those preparing to take crucial exams are particularly jittery. The gaokao, China’s single university-entrance exam, is usually held in June. This year it will probably be delayed, says Xu Liangdi of China Policy, a think-tank, although the government has so far made no announcement.

Around 245,000 students in Britain were expecting in May and June to sit their A-levels, the exams that determine which university—if any—will grant them a place. On March 18th the government announced that those exams would be cancelled. Boris Johnson, the prime minister, said that the government would make sure that children still got “the qualifications they need and deserve for their academic career.” That may go some way to assuaging fears that children whose parents lack the cash or knowledge to compensate for schools closing would be worst affected.

For American students the stakes are lower, in part because their transcript —based on their academic performance throughout the year—is the most important part of their university application, but also because they can take SATs, the exams used in college admissions, all year round. Most sit them in the spring. For those hoping to start university in 2021, the March and May tests have been cancelled. They will be rescheduled, however, and students may be able to take them at home.

Nonetheless universities may have to be more accommodating. Covid-19 will “absolutely” affect the admissions procedure for Miami University in Ohio, says Bethany Perkins, the director of admissions—particularly the deadlines. Students with offers from American universities have to choose which to accept by May 1st. But students worry that they will have to make an important decision without being able to visit any campuses. Along with their parents, some are calling for the date to be pushed back to June 1st. Colleges have yet to react. Harvard says it is not changing its application process.

The disruption has lent ammunition to those who disapprove of high-stakes exams, which some education theorists want to scrap. Some institutions have already made SATs optional. Others, including Miami University, were considering doing so. The upheaval caused by covid-19 might accelerate that process, says Ms Perkins. But the flaws of other kinds of assessment may become clear in the coming months, bolstering those who believe that SATs and other high-stakes exams, which offer a relatively objective and transparent measure of ability, are the least unfair way to decide who gets into university.

The pandemic won’t change this. But it will highlight the strengths and weaknesses of teaching online. Online resources are increasingly popular but few countries boast a developed digital infrastructure for all students. A survey by Teacher Tapp, an app, of over 6,000 teachers in Britain found that only 40% of those in state schools would be able to broadcast a video lesson, compared with 69% of teachers at independent schools. Elena Silva of New America, a think-tank, says that few American states have adequate kit for teaching online. “Most states are not that prepared. This is a moment of forced opportunity.”

Teachers have little choice but to seize it. Since Italy closed its schools and universities on March 5th, teachers’ forums have filled with discussions on the relative merits of Zoom, Moodle and virtual classrooms. Some teachers had been trained to use such technology, but many have faced a steep learning curve. Carla Crosato, a teacher in Treviso, in northern Italy, has been uploading videos in which she explains the novels of Italo Svevo and Luigi Pirandello to her students. “I never thought I’d become a YouTuber at 56,” she says.

Even if teachers manage to broadcast their lessons, students may struggle to join them. Not everyone can get online (see chart). In America 7m school-age children cannot access the internet at home. Lin Kengying of 21st Century Education Research Institute, a think-tank in China, says that the closure of schools since the Lunar new year holiday, which began at the end of January, has led his organisation to reconsider the potential of e-learning. “It hasn’t been smooth,” he says, citing problems such as internet access, scheduling classes, teachers unfamiliar with online tuition, and subjects such as physical education being “awkward” to teach remotely. In China teachers have to submit lesson plans for review by censors, which has led to delays. Students have been spamming the main online teaching app with one-star reviews in an effort to get it removed from the app store. And Xue Hua, a mother of two in Jiangxi province, has been printing out all the learning materials for her 16-year-old son, Guo Guo, because she worries about too much screen-time.

Even done properly, online learning is a poor substitute for the kind that happens in a classroom. On average, students fare worse working online, especially those with less strong academic backgrounds, says Susanna Loeb of Brown University. Online courses can be an asset when students cannot be in school, but she reckons that they are “suboptimal for most” and argues that long periods of time spent away from actual schools will probably lead to children’s education suffering.

Online learning has clear potential. Educational technology powered by artificial intelligence can help children in poor countries with iffy schools—supposing they have internet access. In 2018 researchers found that after four and a half months of using an Indian app called Mindspark, which tests basic language and maths skills, children made more progress in these areas than those in the control group. But the success of such initiatives relies on preparation and organisation, not sudden scrambles to teach existing curriculums to entire populations of students in the midst of a pandemic.

entry.title: Governments are still struggling to get ahead of the coronavirus
entry.content:
OF THE SUPPOSED five stages of grief, humanity’s response to the covid-19 pandemic has seemed stuck in the first three: denial (it will not happen to us), anger (it’s another country’s fault, or our government’s) and bargaining (if we make modest changes to our ways of life, it will leave us alone). Monday March 16th may have been the day when the last vestiges of these coping strategies evaporated. Much of the world moved on to the next stage, depression—the heart-sinking realisation that billions of lives will be seriously disrupted for weeks and probably months; that, before it is over, many people will die; and that the economic implications are beyond dire.

As stockmarkets in America experienced one of the worst days in their history, in many countries the incremental stepping up of relatively modest measures against the virus gave way to Draconian restrictions on travel and on daily life. This seemed to resolve a debate between advocates of two very different approaches.

Some Western governments, notably America’s and Britain’s, had adopted much milder measures. Britain’s apparently calculated that, since the worst was still to come, there was no point in sowing panic and resentment among its people by imposing restrictions that were still premature. Both countries were slow to institute widespread testing to get a better sense of how many people were already infected. “Relax, we’re doing great,” President Donald Trump told Americans on March 15th. In contrast, three days earlier, Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, had called the pandemic “the worst public-health crisis for a generation” but his government’s response did not involve closing schools, as many countries had done, nor banning mass gatherings.

Other countries had already instituted harsher measures, and seemed to have had some success. The central Chinese province of Hubei, home to 60m people, had in effect been in quarantine for nearly two months. South Korea had tested hundreds of thousands of people and enabled people to check whether they might have had contact with the infected on a website showing their movements. European countries had begun also to shut down, starting with Italy, site of the continent’s worst outbreak.

In recent days, China has started easing restrictions and is cautiously hailing at least a partial victory over the virus. But that may be premature, as a second wave of infections re-imported from abroad remains possible. Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan have this week seen renewed infections after apparently suppressing the virus’s spread.

After March 16th, the differences between countries seem less stark. Mr Johnson told people to work from home if they can, not to hold big gatherings, to steer clear of pubs and restaurants and to quarantine their whole households for 14 days if one member shows symptoms of infection (schools remained open for the time being). The change in approach was justified by saying, “It looks as though we’re now approaching the fast growth part of the upward curve”, and, in other briefings, by alarm at new data showing the extent of the crisis in Italy. Britain is also discouraging non-essential travel, but has not banned it. The same day in America, Mr Trump issued tighter new guidelines, including that people should avoid gatherings of ten or more people. In France, President Emmanuel Macron declared “we are at war” with the virus.

Meanwhile, the number of countries closing their borders to arrivals from countries with infections has grown to over 80, including America, Australia, Canada, Japan, Russia. They also include members of the European Union and of the Schengen free-travel zone, which approved a 30-day closure of their external borders.

A joint statement on March 16th from leaders of the G7 seemed to herald a new phase of welcome international co-operation after a period when squabbling seemed more noticeable than co-ordination. It promised “a strongly co-ordinated international approach, based on science and evidence.” But even that appeared to want to make a political point, adding that the approach should be “consistent with our democratic values and utilising the strengths of private enterprise”, as if to add: “Are you listening, China?”

In fact, the boasts of international solidarity and a shared approach are hollow. Countries are still pursuing divergent strategies, and in some cases banning exports of medical supplies. They seem to be competing to show that their method stands the best chance of success. Not long after Mr Johnson announced Britain’s latest measures, for example, Mr Macron, unveiled France’s much more sweeping approach. From March 17th nobody is to leave their home except to shop for essentials, attend medical appointments, or do jobs that cannot be done at home. Schools, universities, cafes, cinemas, hairdressers and museums had already closed.

The world’s two most powerful countries, America and China, are meanwhile indulging in a blame game. Also on March 16th Mr Trump irritated China’s leaders by referring to “the Chinese virus”. China’s foreign-ministry spokesman urged America to stop the “despicable practice” of stigmatising China. But Chinese officials have also been guilty, with one lending his name to a bizarre online conspiracy theory that the virus was made by the American army and brought into China. Tensions between the two countries worsened on Tuesday when China announced it was expelling reporters from the New York Times, Washington Post and Wall Street Journal. It described the move as “reciprocal”—a response to Mr Trump’s decision last month to cap the numbers in America of journalists working for five state-controlled Chinese news outlets.

If international co-operation on the battle against the virus is going badly, then at least central banks and other monetary authorities are working in cahoots to contain the economic fall-out. The move by America’s Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to close to zero in an emergency intervention on Sunday is in lockstep with the decisions of many other central banks. The record-setting crash on the American stockmarkets the following day was a reflection of how little impact investors and traders think monetary policy can have on the recession —or even depression—that may be looming.

More important are central banks’ efforts to keep credit flowing before companies and the banks they owe money to seize up. On March 17th the Fed announced that, as during the financial crisis of 2008-09, it will start buying up companies’ short-term debt (“commercial paper”). But in the end, the banks and companies are probably going to need their governments’ help—either to spend directly to keep businesses open, or to provide guarantees to the banks.

Most big economies have announced—or are about to unveil—big spending packages to support the economy. Also on March 17th Britain’s finance minister, Rishi Sunak, promised £330bn ($400bn) in lending, grants and guarantees to keep businesses going through the virus-induced slump. France has promised €45bn ($50bn) to help businesses. Mr Trump’s administration wants Congress to approve $850bn in extra spending.

The plight of financial institutions is not yet nearly bad as it was during the global financial crisis. But the disagreements over how to handle covid-19 and how to attribute blame for its spread do not augur well for future co-operation to stop financial systems sinking to those lows. And, in the meantime, every antiviral and economic measure governments introduce seems to serve partly to heighten the sense that policymakers are floundering against an adversary they still do not understand; and hence to worsen the mounting panic.

entry.title: 假设检验
entry.content:
基本思想和概念

某厂生产的合金强度服从正态分布N(θ,16)N(\theta,16)N(θ,16)，其中θ\thetaθ的设计值为110(Pa)。为了保证质量，工厂每天都有例行检查，要求合金平均强度不低于110.某天，取25块合金，测得的xˉ=108\bar x=108xˉ=108，问当日的生产是否正常？

  1. 这是在给定的总体和样本下，要求对命题"总体合金平均强度不低于110"作出判断。这类问题就是假设检验问题。
  2. 命题"总体合金平均强度不低于110"仅涉及参数θ\thetaθ的范围，因此该命题可以理解为参数θ\thetaθ属于以下集合中的哪一个。$$\Theta={\theta:\theta\geqslant 100},\Theta={\theta:\theta< 100}$$统计学中，这两个非空不相交的参数集合称为假设。
  3. 通过样本对一个假设作出具体判断的规则称为检验或检验法则。结果如果是否定这个命题，则称拒绝这个假设，反之称接受这个假设。

假设检验的基本步骤

建立统计假设

对于参数假设检验，令Θ\ThetaΘ为参数空间，Θ0⊂Θ&Θ0≠∅,Θ1⊂Θ&Theta0Θ1=∅\Theta_0\subset \Theta \& \Theta_0\neq \varnothing,\Theta_1\subset \Theta\& Theta_0\Theta_1=\varnothingΘ0​⊂Θ&Θ0​​=∅,Θ1​⊂Θ&Theta0​Θ1​=∅。
则称命题H0:θ∈Θ0H_0:\theta \in \Theta_0H0​:θ∈Θ0​为一个原假设或零假设(null hypothesis)
命题H1:θ∈Θ1H_1:\theta \in \Theta_1H1​:θ∈Θ1​为H0H_0H0​的对立假设或备择假设(alternative hypothesis)
如果Θ0\Theta_0Θ0​只有一个点，则称H0H_0H0​为简单假设，否则就称复杂假设。
当H0H_0H0​为简单假设时，可以写成H0:θ=θ0H_0:\theta = \theta_0H0​:θ=θ0​
此时备择假设有三种可能：

  1. H1′:θ≠θ0H_1':\theta \neq \theta_0H1′​:θ​=θ0​ – 双侧假设或双边假设
  2. H1′′:θ<θ0H_1'':\theta < \theta_0H1′′​:θ<θ0​ – 单侧假设或单边假设
  3. H1′′′:θ>θ0H_1''':\theta > \theta_0H1′′′​:θ>θ0​ – 单侧假设或单边假设

选择检验统计量，给出拒绝域的形式

有了具体的样本后，就可以根据检验法则决定是接受H0H_0H0​还是拒绝H0H_0H0​，即相当于把整个样本空间划分为两个不相交的部分WWW和W‾\overline WW，当样本属于WWW时，拒绝H0H_0H0​，否则接受H0H_0H0​。于是，称WWW为该检验的拒绝域。

备择假设有三种可能,拒绝域也有三种(例：W={(x1,…,xn):xˉ⩽c}={xˉ⩽c}W=\{(x_1,\dots,x_n):\bar x \leqslant c\}=\{\bar x \leqslant c\}W={(x1​,…,xn​):xˉ⩽c}={xˉ⩽c},c是由)。如下图(统计量符合正态分布)，绿色阴影部分对应的x轴区域即为拒绝域

判断准则：样本在拒绝域内，则拒绝H0H_0H0​，否则接受。

选择显著性水平

因为样本是随机的，所以当我们用某检验作判断时，即人为的确定了一个明确的界限，由于随机性，可能会犯如下两类错误：

样本数据 总体 H0H_0H0​为真 总体 H1H_1H1​为真
(x1,…,xn)∈W(x_1,\dots,x_n)\in W(x1​,…,xn​)∈W 犯第一类错误 正确
(x1,…,xn)∈W‾(x_1,\dots,x_n)\in \overline W(x1​,…,xn​)∈W 正确 犯第二类错误

第一类错误称为拒真错误，第二类错误称为取伪错误。其发生概率分别记为：
α=P{X∈W∣H0}\alpha=P\{X\in W|H_0\}α=P{X∈W∣H0​}
β=P{X∈W‾∣H1}\beta=P\{X\in \overline W|H_1\}β=P{X∈W∣H1​}

显著性检验：对检验问题H0:θ∈Θ0 vs H1:θ∈Θ1H_0:\theta \in \Theta_0 \ vs \ H_1:\theta\in \Theta_1H0​:θ∈Θ0​ vs H1​:θ∈Θ1​，如果对任意的θ∈Θ0\theta \in \Theta_0θ∈Θ0​，都有g(θ)⩽αg(\theta)\leqslant \alphag(θ)⩽α，则称该检验是显著性水平为α\alphaα的显著性检验，简称水平为α\alphaα的检验。g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ)是功效函数，定义为样本观测值落在拒绝域内的概率(上表第一行)。当总体情况实际支持H0H_0H0​时，为拒真错误发生的概率函数，即相当于α(θ)\alpha(\theta)α(θ)。当总体情况实际支持H1H_1H1​时，为取伪错误不发生的概率函数，即相当于1−β(θ)1-\beta(\theta)1−β(θ)。

提出显著性检验概念的目的是要控制犯第一类错误的概率α\alphaα。但也不能过小，过小会导致犯第二类错误的概率增大。故α\alphaα常用0.05,0.1,0.01这几个值。

给出拒绝域

给定α\alphaα之后，根据假设，统计量和分布函数相应的α\alphaα分位数，1−α1-\alpha1−α分位数，或α2&1−α2\frac \alpha 2\& 1-\frac \alpha22α​&1−2α​分位数，计算出临界值，写出具体的拒绝域。

作出判断

样本在拒绝域内，则拒绝H0H_0H0​，否则接受。

p值检验

定义:在一个假设检验问题中，利用样本数据能够做出拒接原假设的最小显著性水平称为检测的p值。p值的计算，就是将参数原来的值代入选定的统计量，得到统计量的值，算出这个值在多少分位数的位置，这个分位数就是p。

由p和α\alphaα也可以得出检验结论：

  • 如果α⩾p\alpha\geqslant pα⩾p,则在显著性水平α\alphaα下拒绝原假设。
  • 如果α<p\alpha< pα<p,则在显著性水平α\alphaα下接受原假设。

entry.title: pandas基础
entry.content:
pandas数据结构

Series

类似于字典的一维数组型对象。包含值序列和索引(index)。默认索引为0~N-1。可以用ser.values和ser.index属性分别获得值和索引。

在建立Series时，可以指定索引。pd.Series(sdata, index=['a','c','b','d'])。

  • sdata可以是数组或字典。如果是字典的话，字典的key不在index指定的数组中的，这个键值对就不会存到Series对象中，如果index指定的索引没有值，则置为NaN。
  • pandas使用isnull,notnull检查缺失值。和numpy类似,Series对象和pd都有这些方法。
  • 索引自动对齐：两个Series相加，索引相同的加在一起，不同的值都设为NaN。
  • ser.index也可以用于修改索引值

Series对象和其索引都有name属性。默认为空，需要显式指定。ser.name=xx,ser.index.name=xxx

DataFrame

DataFrame表示的矩阵的数据表。它包含已排序的列集合，每一列可以是不同的值类型。DataFrame既有行索引，又有列索引。

构建DataFrame的常用方式

基本方法(frame = pd.DataFrame(data))

  • frame.head(): 只选出头部的5行
  • pd.DataFrame(data, columns=arr1, index=arr2):构建DataFrame的同时显示指定行索引和列索引及其顺序。
  • frame['state']:选取列，得到一个Series对象。如果state列不存在则创建。frame.state无法创建。另外，frame.state这种索引方式，state必须是有效的Python变量名。选取的列是视图不是拷贝

索引：

  • 索引可以用数组重新赋值，但不能单独修改某一个索引
  • pandas索引对象可以重复

基本功能

重建索引

obj.reindex(index)
如果是Series，则会将数据按新的索引重新排列。
如果是DataFrame，默认重建行索引，可以用关键字参数指定修改行索引或列索引或都改。DataFrame还有另一种重建方式。frame.loc(rowarr,colarr)。

reindex的主要参数：

  • index
  • method:允许在重建索引时插入值。'ffill’为前向填充(0有值1没值则，将0的值赋给1)，'bfill’为后向填充。
  • limit,tolerance:前向填充或后向填充的填充限制
  • fill_value:重建索引时引入缺失数据时使用该值替代。

删除

是直接操作原对象。

frame.drop(label=None,axis=0,inplace=True)：label可以是单个值，也可以是列表，表示要删除的行或列。axis指定是行还是列，默认是行，0.可指定为columus或1.inplace表示清除被删除的属性。默认为False，若指定为True，则frame.drop()返回None。

索引选择和过滤

DataFrame和Series的索引和numpy类似，但是DataFrame和Series可以用非整数的索引值(如果索引不是整数的话)。用非整数索引值切片，和普通切片不同，是包含尾部的。

DataFrame的特殊索引方式
frame.loc[rows, columns]:使用轴标签选择数据
frame.iloc[rowsint, colsint]:使用整数标签选择数据
frame.at(label_i, label_j):选择某个数据
frame.iat(i, j)选择某个数据
这里row,col都可以用切片表示。

数据对齐和Series差不多，相同的相加，不同的值都设为NaN。
DataFrame的add方法可以添加fill_value参数，用以处理缺失值。
df1.add(df2, fill_value=0):缺失值不是用0填充，而是用在数组中的位置值填充。
df2.radd(df1)：效果同上。
加了r表示将操作数反过来。

DataFrame和Series间的算术操作

从DataFrame中减去Series时，减法在DataFrame的每一行都进行了操作。这就是所谓的广播机制。默认将Series的索引和DataFrame的列索引进行匹配，并广播到各行。可用axis=0或axis='inex'修改为在行上匹配，列上广播。

通用函数

Numpy的通用函数基本对pandas对象也有用。DataFrame对象，默认在行上操作，可用axis修改。

frame.apply(f, axis=0):在行上应用某个函数。返回值可以是单个值，也可以是数组。

排序和排名

obj.sort_index()：返回新的，排序好的对象。DataFrame中可以指定axis决定排序的轴。默认是升序，可用ascending=False来指定用降序排序。DataFrame中可以用by参数指定用于排序的键。默认缺失值排在最后。

排名(rank)：对数组从1到有效数据点总数，分配名次的操作。遇到大小相同的数时，默认取平均排名。

平级关系打破方法：

  • average:取平均，默认值
  • min:取最小排名，如rank为4，5的两个4，都取4.0作为rank值
  • max:取最大排名。
  • first:先出现的顺位靠前，rank值小。如rank为4，5的两个4，先出现的取4.0作为rank值。
  • dense:类似min，但组间排名总增加1，而不是组中相等元素的数量。

统计方法

pandas对象的统计方法都内建了处理缺失值的功能。即自动排除NaN。可以禁用skipna=False。DataFrame默认是统计一行的统计量，可以改。

idxmin(),idxmax()返回最大最小值的索引值。

frame.describe()返回多个汇总统计信息。

Series中corr方法计算相关性，cov计算协方差。DataFrame的corr和cov方法会以DataFrame的形式返回相关性和协方差矩阵。
DataFrame中corrwith方法可以计算行或列与另一个Series或DataFrame的相关性。

entry.title: numpy基础
entry.content:
ndarray-numpy数组对象

生成ndarray

  1. np.array|np.asarray:根据python列表生成ndarray。asarray只在参数不是ndarray时生成新的ndarray。
  2. np.arange(n):生成一个由0到n-1组成的ndarray
  3. 其他生成函数:ones,zeros,empty,full,xx_like,eye,idetity

例如：

PS:ndarray的几个属性

  • narr.shape:数组的每个维度的元素个数信息，即上面构造数组时传入的(2,3)。
  • narr.ndim:数组的维度
  • narr.dtype:数组元素的数据类型，创建数组时可以用dtype参数指定，默认为float64。另外，可用narr.astype(float)修改数据类型，支持将数字字符串转换为数字，这总会产生一个新数组。

numpy数组算术

  1. 任何在两个等尺寸数组之间的算术操作都是逐元素的操作。
  2. 带标量的算术操作会把标量传给每一个元素。比较操作也一样，结果会产生一个bool数组。如果是赋值操作，则所有元素都会被赋予一样的值。
  3. 同尺寸数组之间的比较会产生一个bool数组。

索引和切片

切片

数组切片和子数组实际上是原数组的视图(numpy是设计用来处理大数据的，尽量避免了复制操作)。修改切片相当于修改原数组相应部分。

使用arr[5:8].copy可以得到数组切片的一份拷贝。

布尔索引

索引数组时可以传入布尔值数组，表示这个元素或这个低维数组要不要。因此，布尔值数组长度必须和数组轴索引长度一致。布尔索引选择数据时，总是生成数据的拷贝。
通过numpy算术和布尔索引可以实现一些很实用的功能。比如，把数据中的负值设为0等。

注意：即使布尔值数组长度必须和数组轴索引长度不一致，也不会报错，使用时需要小心。Python关键字and,or不能用于布尔索引，应使用&,|.

神奇索引

numpy术语，用于描述使用整数数组进行索引。用于选出一个特定顺序的子集。传递多个索引数组时，得到的却是索引数组相应位置元素组成的元组对应的元素的数组。

总是将数据复制到新的数组中。

转置和换轴

都是返回视图。

  1. 转置:arr.T或arr.transpose(0,1)
  2. 换轴:arr.swapaxes(0,1)(如果是三维数组，则arr.transpose(1,0,2)起的效果一样)

通用函数

一元

  • abs、fabs:计算整数、浮点数或复数的绝对值。对于非复数值，可以使用更快的fabs。
  • sqrt,square，exp: 开方，平方,自然指数exe^xex
  • log,log10,log2,log1p:对数，第一个为自然对数，最后一个为1+p为底的对数。
  • sign:计算每个元素的符号值(1:整数，0，-1:负数)
  • ceil:返回大于等于该值的最小整数。
  • floor: 返回小于等于该值的最大整数。
  • rint:四舍五入，保留dtype。
  • modf:将数组的小数和整数部分以两个独立数组的形式返回。
  • isnan:返回布尔型数组，表示哪些值是NaN（非数字）。
  • isfinite/isinf:返回布尔型数组，表示哪些元素是有穷的（非inf，非NaN）或那些是无穷的。
  • cos,cosh,sin,sinh,tan,tanh:普通型和双曲型三角函数。
  • arccos,arccosh,arcsin,arcsinh,asrtan,arctanh:反三角函数。
  • logical_not:计算个元素的not x的真值，相当于~arr。

二元

  • add,substract,multiply,divide,floor_divide,power:+,-,*,/,//,^
  • maximum,fmax:返回两个数组中较大值组成的数组。fmax忽略NaN。
  • minimum,fmin:同上。
  • mod:求模，即求余数。
  • copysign:第二个数组的符号，复制给第一个数组。
  • greater,greater_equal,less,less_equal,equal,not_euqal:元素级比较运算，最终产生布尔型数组，相当于>,>=,<,<=,==,!=。
  • logical_and,logical_or,logical_xor:元素级真值运算，相当于&，|，^。

面向数组编程

np.meshgrid(arr1, arr2):arr1复制len(arr1)份，arr2每个元素复制len(arr2)份并且每个元素及其复制组成一个数组。即arr1本身横着，向下竖着复制，arr2本身竖着，向右横着复制。

np.sort()：排序，可加参数，表示在哪个轴向上排序。返回的是数组的拷贝。arr.sort()是对原数组按位置排序。

np.where(cond, xarr, yarr):三元表达式的向量化版本。如果cond中相应元素为True，则取xarr中的元素，否则取yarr中的元素。数组必须是同等大小的数组。另外，xarr和yarr可以是标量。当他们是标量时，可以看作是和cond数组同尺寸的值全为指定标量的数组。

典型用法：根据一个数组生成另一个数组。

聚合函数

可以直接调用数组实例的方法，也可以使用顶层的NumPy函数。

  • sum:空数组的sum为0
  • mean:空数组的mean为NaN
  • std,var:标准差和方差，可以选择自由度调整(默认分母是n)
  • min,max
  • argmin,argmax:最大值和最小值的位置
  • cumsum:从第0个元素开始的累积和
  • cumprod:从第1个元素开始的累积积

mean,sum等函数可以接受一个可选参数axis，用于指定计算给定轴上的统计值，形成一个下降一维的数组。

cumsun,cumprod会返回一个等规模的数组。也可以指定轴向，进行低维度的切片。

布尔数组的方法

  • all:数组中所有元素都为True才返回True
  • any:数组中至少有一个True则返回True
  • 用sum可以统计布尔数组中用几个True

集合操作

np.unique()：返回一维数组中唯一值排序后的数组。相当于sorted(set(arr))。

np.in1d():检查数组中的值是否在另一个数组中，是则为True，否则为False，最后返回一个布尔数组

其他：

  • intersect1d(x, y):交集，并排序
  • union1d(x, y):并集，并排序
  • setdiff1d(x, y):差集
  • setxor1d(x, y):异或集，X∪Y−X∩YX\cup Y-X\cap YX∪Y−X∩Y

线性代数

点积：x.dot(y)或np.dot(x, y)或x @ y

numpy.linalg函数集：

  • diag():将方阵的对角元素作为一维数组返回，反过来，将一维数组转换成方阵，其他元素为0.
  • trace():对角元素的和
  • det():行列式
  • eig():特征值
  • inv():逆矩阵
  • pinv():Moore-Penrose伪逆
  • qr():QR分解
  • svd():奇异值分解
  • solve():求Ax=bAx=bAx=b的解，A是方阵
  • lstsq():求Ax=bAx=bAx=b的最小二乘解

伪随机数

np.random中的函数

  • seed():修改随机种子
  • shuffle():随机排序一个序列
  • rand():从U∼(0,1)U\sim (0,1)U∼(0,1)均匀分布中抽样，没参数就抽一个，参数可选，所有参数组成最终输出数组的shape
  • randint(low, high=None, size=None, dtype=‘l’):给定范围内抽整数.size可指定shape
  • randn():从标准正态分布从抽样，没参数就抽一个，参数可选，所有参数组成最终输出数组的shape
  • binomial(n, p, size=None):二项分布
  • normal(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):N(loc,scale2)N(loc, scale^2)N(loc,scale2)，默认为标准正态分布。
  • beta(a, b, size=None):贝塔分布
  • chisquare(df, size=None):卡方分布χ2(n)\chi^2(n)χ2(n),其中n叫做自由度。
  • gamma(shape, scale=1.0, size=None):Ga(shape,scale)Ga(shape, scale)Ga(shape,scale)
  • uniform():U∼(0,1)U\sim (0,1)U∼(0,1)

依概率收敛

设{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}为一随机变量序列，XXX为一随机变量，如果对任意的ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0有

P(∣xn−X∣⩾ε)→0(n→∞)或P(∣xn−X∣<ε)→1(n→∞)P(|x_n-X|\geqslant\varepsilon)\to 0(n\to\infin)\text{或}P(|x_n-X|<\varepsilon)\to 1(n\to\infin) P(∣xn​−X∣⩾ε)→0(n→∞)或P(∣xn​−X∣<ε)→1(n→∞)

则称{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}依概率收敛于XXX，记作Xn→PXX_n\xrightarrow{P}XXn​P​X。其含义为：绝对偏差小于任一给定量的可能性随着nnn增大而逐渐接近1。(即使有个别偏差较大，也不会影响整体趋势)

大数定律

伯努利大数定律

设SnS_nSn​为nnn重伯努利试验中事件AAA发生的次数，ppp为AAA发生的概率，则对任意ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0，有

lim⁡n→∞P(∣Snn−p∣<ε)=1\lim_{n\to \infin}P(|\frac {S_n}{n}-p|<\varepsilon)=1 n→∞lim​P(∣nSn​​−p∣<ε)=1

伯努利大数定律说明：随着nnn的增大，事件AAA发生的频率Snn\frac {S_n}{n}nSn​​和其概率ppp的偏差小于给定精度的概率越来远大，逐渐接近于1。这就是在试验次数足够大时，用频率估计概率可行的原理。

大树定律的一般形式

伯努利大数定律讨论的是一个相互独立同分布的随机变量序列{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}，其共同分布为两点分布b∼(1,p)b\sim(1,p)b∼(1,p)，即记

Xi={1,第i次试验中事件A发生0,第i次试验中事件A不发生X_i=\begin{cases} 1,\text{第i次试验中事件A发生}\\ 0,\text{第i次试验中事件A不发生} \end{cases} Xi​={1,第i次试验中事件A发生0,第i次试验中事件A不发生​

则{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}是独立的两点分布随机变量序列。则该序列前n个随机变量之和为Sn=∑i=1nXiS_n=\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_iSn​=∑i=1n​Xi​，则

Snn=1n∑i=1nXip=E(1n∑i=1nXi)=1n∑i=1nE(Xi)\frac {S_n}{n}=\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i \quad p=E(\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i)=\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}E(X_i) nSn​​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​p=E(n1​i=1∑n​Xi​)=n1​i=1∑n​E(Xi​)

则伯努利大数定律可写成

lim⁡n→∞P(∣1n∑i=1nXi−1n∑i=1nE(Xi)∣<ε)=1\lim_{n\to \infin}P(|\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i-\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}E(X_i)|<\varepsilon)=1 n→∞lim​P(∣n1​i=1∑n​Xi​−n1​i=1∑n​E(Xi​)∣<ε)=1

上式被定义为大数定律的一般形式，只要随机变量序列{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}具有形如该式的性质，则称该随机变量序列{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}服从大树定律。

切比雪夫大数定律

设{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}为一两两不相关的随机变量序列，若每个XiX_iXi​的方差存在且有共同的上界，即Var(X)⩽cVar(X)\leqslant cVar(X)⩽c，则{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}服从大数定律。

马尔科夫大数定律

马尔科夫条件:

1n2Var(∑i=1nXi)→0\frac {1}{n^2}Var(\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i)\to 0 n21​Var(i=1∑n​Xi​)→0

对随机变量序列{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}，若马尔科夫条件成立，则{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}服从大树定律。以上证明都要用到切比雪夫不等式。

辛钦大数定律

设{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}为一独立同分布的随机变量序列，若XiX_iXi​的数学期望存在，则{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}服从大数定律。即，设E(X)=μE(X)=\muE(X)=μ，则

lim⁡n→∞P(∣1n∑i=1nXi−μ)∣<ε)=1\lim_{n\to \infin}P(|\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i-\mu)|<\varepsilon)=1 n→∞lim​P(∣n1​i=1∑n​Xi​−μ)∣<ε)=1

其含义为：若对随机变量XXX独立重复的观察nnn次，则当nnn足够大时，可以把平均观察值1n∑i=1nXi\displaystyle\frac 1n\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_in1​i=1∑n​Xi​作为E(X)E(X)E(X)的近似值。

中心极限定理

大数定律讨论的是什么条件下，随机变量序列的算数平均依概率收敛到其期望的算数平均。中心极限定理讨论的是什么条件下，独立随机变量序列和Yn=∑i=1nXi\displaystyle Y_n=\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_iYn​=i=1∑n​Xi​的分布函数会收敛于正态分布。

林德伯格-莱维中心极限定理

设{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}为一独立同分布的随机变量序列，且E(Xi)=μ,Var(Xi)=σ2>0E(X_i)=\mu,Var(X_i)=\sigma^2>0E(Xi​)=μ,Var(Xi​)=σ2>0存在，若记

Yn∗=∑i=1nXi−nμσnY_n^*=\frac {\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i-n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt n} Yn∗​=σn​i=1∑n​Xi​−nμ​

则对任意实数yyy，有

lim⁡n→∞P(Yn∗<y)=Φ(y)=12π∫−∞ye−t22dt\lim_{n\to \infin}P(Y_n^*< y)=\Phi(y)=\frac {1}{\sqrt {2\pi}}\int_{-\infin}^{y}e^{-\frac {t^2}{2}}dt n→∞lim​P(Yn∗​<y)=Φ(y)=2π​1​∫−∞y​e−2t2​dt

棣莫弗-拉普拉斯中心极限定理

设nnn重伯努利试验中事件AAA发生的次数为{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}，ppp为AAA发生的概率，且记

Yn∗=Sn−npnp(1−p)Y_n^*=\frac {S_n-np}{\sqrt {np(1-p)}} Yn∗​=np(1−p)​Sn​−np​

则对任意实数yyy有，

lim⁡n→∞P(Yn∗<y)=Φ(y)=12π∫−∞ye−t22dt\lim_{n\to \infin}P(Y_n^*< y)=\Phi(y)=\frac {1}{\sqrt {2\pi}}\int_{-\infin}^{y}e^{-\frac {t^2}{2}}dt n→∞lim​P(Yn∗​<y)=Φ(y)=2π​1​∫−∞y​e−2t2​dt

这是专门针对二项分布的，也被称为"二项分布的正态近似"。一般，泊松近似用于ppp较小，npnpnp适中的情形；正态近似在np>5np>5np>5和n(1−p)>5n(1-p)>5n(1−p)>5时比较好用。

注意：

  1. 二项分布是离散分布，而正态分布是连续分布，所以，近似时做一些修正可以提高精度。若k1<k2k_1< k_2k1​<k2​且都是整数，一般这样修正P(k1⩽Sn⩽k2)=P((k1−0.5<Sn<k2+0.5)P(k_1\leqslant S_n \leqslant k_2)=P((k_1-0.5 < S_n < k_2+0.5)P(k1​⩽Sn​⩽k2​)=P((k1​−0.5<Sn​<k2​+0.5)
  2. 对于二项分布的计算，用修正的正态近似还可得

P(Sn=k)=P(k−0.5<Sn<k+0.5)=P(k−0.5−npnpq<Sn−0.5−npnpq<k+0.5−npnpq)≈12πe−12(k−npnpq)2⋅1npq\begin{aligned} P(S_n=k)&=P(k-0.5 < S_n < k+0.5)\\ &=P(\frac {k-0.5-np}{\sqrt {npq}}<\frac {S_n-0.5-np}{\sqrt {npq}}<\frac {k+0.5-np}{\sqrt {npq}})\\ &\approx\frac {1}{\sqrt {2\pi}}e^{-\frac 12(\frac {k-np}{\sqrt {npq}})^2}\cdot\frac {1}{\sqrt {npq}} \end{aligned}P(Sn​=k)​=P(k−0.5<Sn​<k+0.5)=P(npq​k−0.5−np​<npq​Sn​−0.5−np​<npq​k+0.5−np​)≈2π​1​e−21​(npq​k−np​)2⋅npq​1​​

entry.title: 6 Habits of Super Learners
entry.content:
Becoming a super learner is one of the most important skills you need to succeed in the 21st century. In the age technological change, staying ahead depends on continual self-education — a lifelong mastery of new models, skills and ideas.
In a world that’s changing fast, the ability to learn a new skill as fast as possible is quickly becoming a necessity. The good news is, you don’t need a natural gift to be better at learning something new even when you have a full-time career.
Many polymaths (people who have excelled in diverse pursuits) — including Charles Darwin, Leonardo da Vinci and the Nobel prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman — claimed not to have exceptional natural intelligence.
We all have enough brainpower to master a new discipline — we use the right tools, approaches, or apply what we learn correctly. Almost anyone can learn anything — with the right technique.
Better learning approaches can make the process enjoyable. The key to rapid skill acquisition isn’t complicated. If you aim to learn a new skill to improve your career this year, some of these habits can be useful for you.

Super learners read a lot

Reading is to the mind what exercise is to your body. It gives us the freedom to roam the expanse of space, time, history, and offer a deeper view of ideas, concepts, emotions, and body of knowledge.
Your brain on books is active — growing, changing and making new connections and different patterns, depending on the type of material you’re reading. Highly successful learners read a lot.
In fact, many of the most successful people share this appreciation for reading — they don’t see reading as a chore but as an opportunity to improve their lives, careers and businesses.
Elon Musk grew up reading two books a day, according to his brother. Bill Gates reads 50 books per year. Mark Zuckerberg reads at least one book every two weeks. Warren Buffett spends five to six hours per day reading five newspapers and 500 pages of corporate reports.
In a world where information is the new currency, reading is the best source of continuous learning, knowledge and acquiring more of that currency.

Super learners view learning as a process

Learning is a journey, a discovery of new knowledge, not a destination.
It’s an enjoyable lifelong process — a self-directed and self-paced journey of discovery. Understanding any topic, idea or new mindset requires not only keen observation but more fundamentally, the sustained curiosity.
“A learning journey is a curated collection of learning assets, both formal and informal, that can be used to acquire skills for a specific role and/or technology area,” writes Sonia Malik of IBM.
Learning is an investment that usually pays for itself in increased earnings. More than ever, learning is for life if you want to stay relevant, indispensable and thrive in the changing world of work.
Super learners value the process. They don’t have an end goal, they seek consistent improvement. They keep mastering new principles, processes, worldviews, thinking models, etc. The “ongoing, voluntary, and self-motivated” pursuit of knowledge is important for their maturity.

They adopt a growth mindset

You can’t go wrong cultivating a growth mindset — a learning theory developed by Dr Carol Dweck that revolves around the belief that you can improve intelligence, ability and performance.
“The illiterate of the 21st century will not be those who cannot read and write, but those who cannot learn, unlearn and relearn,” argues Alvin Toffler, a writer, futurist, and businessman known for his works discussing modern technologies.
Cultivating a growth or adaptable mindset can help you focus more on your most desirable goals in life. It may influence your motivation and could make you more readily able to see opportunities to learn and grow your abilities.
The ability to keep an open-mind, acquire better knowledge and apply it when necessary can significantly improve your life and career.

Super learners teach others what they know

According to research, learners retain approximately 90% of what they learn when they explain/teach the concept to someone else, or use it immediately.
Teaching others what you know is one of the most effective ways to learn, remember and recall new information. Psychologists, call it the “retrieval practice”. It’s one of the most reliable ways of building stronger memory traces.
Learn by teaching someone else a topic in simple terms so you can quickly pinpoint the holes in your knowledge. It’s a mental model coined by the famous physicist Richard Feynman.
Known as the “Great Explainer,” Feynman was revered for his ability to clearly illustrate dense topics like quantum physics for virtually anybody. The Feynman Technique is laid out clearly in James Gleick’s biography, Genius: The Life and Science of Richard Feynman.
The ultimate test of your knowledge is your capacity to transfer it to another. A better way to learn, process, retain and remember information is to learn half the time and share half the time. Example, instead of completing a book, aim to read 50 percent and try recalling, sharing, or writing down the key ideas you have learned before proceeding.

Effective learners take care of their brains

Keeping your brain healthy keeps it sharp. What you do or don’t do for your brain can significantly change how your record, process and retrieve information. Everyone wants to live an active life for as long as possible. And that goal depends on robust brain health.
That means eating lots of foods associated with slowing cognitive decline — blueberries, vegetables (leafy greens — kale, spinach, broccoli), whole grains, getting protein from fish and legumes and choosing healthy unsaturated fats (olive oil) over saturated fats (butter).
Fruit and vegetables combat age-related oxidative stress that causes wear and tear on brain cells,” says Dr Gary Small, a professor of psychiatry and ageing.
Our brains naturally decline if we do nothing to protect them. However, if you intervene early, you can slow the decline process — it’s easier to protect a healthy brain than to try to repair damage once it is extensive.

They take short breaks, early and often

Downtime is crucial to retaining anything you choose to learn. According to recent research, taking short breaks, early and often, can help you learn things better and even improve your retention rate.
“Everyone thinks you need to ‘practice, practice, practice’ when learning something new. Instead, we found that resting, early and often, maybe just as critical to learning as practice,” said Leonardo G. Cohen, M.D., Ph.D., a senior investigator at NIH’s National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke.
Better breaks help the brain solidify memories during the rest periods. Whatever you choose to learn over time, it’s important to optimise the timing of rest intervals for better results.
Experts at the Louisiana State University’s Center for Academic Success recommends 30–50 minutes sessions. “Anything less than 30 is just not enough, but anything more than 50 is too much information for your brain to take in at one time,” says learning strategies graduate assistant Ellen Dunn.
Our brains’ neural networks need to time process information, so spacing out your learning helps you memorise new information more efficiently — give your brain enough time to rest and recover.

entry.title: 7-modern-life-habits-doing-the-most-damage-to-your-brain
entry.content:
原文链接

In an era of better technology, we are all being rewired to do more to the detriment of our brains. According to experts, our modern lifestyle is chipping away at neural pathways and making us slower, denser and less capable of original thought. Hyperconnectivity is increasingly taking its toll on our brains. In the end, we end up less productive and ineffective.
When it comes to our health, we don’t always think about nurturing our brains the way we nourish our bodies. But to be our most productive self, we need to do more of what improves our brain health, and less of what causes cognitive decline. Start by adjusting your daily habits and avoiding these common modern habits — your mind will thank you.

The brain drain of inactivity

Physical inactivity has its price tags — It’s linked to the development of chronic health problems like heart disease, obesity, depression, dementia, and cancer. Many people are too busy to make time for “basic movement activities” that can slow cognitive decline — walking, cycling, stretching, etc.

Being sedentary changes the shape of certain neurons in the brain, according to a new study in the Journal of Comparative Neurology that suggests a link between inactivity and mental decline.

Regular physical activity can benefit you cognitively — increase brain chemicals which promote better memory and learning, and medically. You know this though. Knowledge of the benefits of exercise is not a problem in the modern world, it’s the application of relevant information.

Think you’re multitasking? Think again

Our smartphones have become Swiss army knives. We use them all the time. We text while we’re walking across the street, catch up on email while commuting, read or listen to podcasts while standing in a queue.

You’ve likely heard that multitasking is bad for your productivity. It turns out, it’s a habit that also rewires the brain and makes you less effective.

Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT and one of the world experts on divided attention, says that our brains are “not wired to multitask well… When people think they’re multitasking, they’re actually just switching from one task to another very rapidly. And every time they do, there’s a cognitive cost in doing so.”

Multitasking also increases the stress hormone cortisol as well as the fight-or-flight hormone adrenaline, which can overstimulate your brain and cause mental fog or scrambled thinking.

Information overload leads to unnecessary overstimulation of the brain

The sheer volume of emails, social updates, and notifications we receive can be overwhelming — it takes a huge bite out of the day for many people. The constant stream of content if not managed can cause stress and lead to decision overload.

“Too Much Information” that, “Information overload is one of the biggest irritations in modern life”, writes Schumpeter of The Economist.

Some people proudly boast of how many things they can juggle in a single day. Glenn Wilson, former visiting professor of psychology at Gresham College, London found out in his research that being in a situation where you are trying to concentrate on a task, and an email is sitting unread in your inbox, can reduce your effective IQ by 10 points.

To maximize your brain every day, use better tools and settings to filter information throughout the day. Be proactive about how you consume media. Prepare your brain to ignore unnecessary information. When you organize your day with these principles in mind, you will likely increase your brain’s efficiency significantly.

Sitting for too long is hurting you

Sitting is one of the worst things we can do for our health. A new UCLA study reports that people who are more sedentary have thinning in brain regions linked to memory.

It finds that sitting isn’t just a physical health risk — it’s a neurological risk as well. The authors write in their paper, “it is possible that sedentary behaviour is a more significant predictor of brain structure, specifically [medial temporal lobe] thickness, and that physical activity, even at higher levels, is not sufficient to offset the harmful effects of sitting for extended periods of time.”

You can reduce the amount of sitting you do by adopting interventions like moderate walking, standing while working, even for just 10 minutes at a time, standup meetings — it offers the opportunity to sit less, move more and conduct short meetings.

All that screen time can negatively impact our mental and emotional wellbeing

Today, face-to-face interactions are increasingly being replaced by digital tools. People spend more time online than ever before.

“Anything with a screen — television, phones, tablets, computers, video games — constitutes screen time,” explains Tom Kersting, a licensed psychotherapist and an expert in the field of mental health and parenting in the digital age. “If the majority of our waking hours entails looking at a screen, then we know it is way too much.”

A face-to-face conversation is incredibly beneficial for your brain. A study by the University of Michigan found that even just 10 minutes per day of conversation with another person improved memory and cognition.
“In our study, socializing was just as effective as more traditional kinds of mental exercise in boosting memory and intellectual performance,” said Oscar Ybarra, a psychologist at the U-M Institute for Social Research (ISR) and a lead author of the study with ISR psychologist Eugene Burnstein and psychologist Piotr Winkielman from the University of California, San Diego.

The lack of true personal interaction limits the brain’s opportunities to make better connections. It can also lead to loneliness and depression — mental conditions that contribute significantly to reduced brain health.
Looking at screens all day can hurt your eyes, ears, neck, shoulders, back, wrists, and forearms. It also interferes with getting a good night’s sleep.

According to experts, excessive screen time has a negative effect on intellectual abilities as well as emotional well-being.
Set clear boundaries with screens to avoid developing detrimental habits. The goal isn’t to avoid screen time entirely, as that’s not realistic in modern life. However, if you’re going to use a device, be mindful.

It’s surprisingly easy for your headphones to damage the parts of the ear vital to healthy hearing

People, by nature, love to switch up the volume. It makes the music sounds more “fun” and immersive. In the age of noise-cancelling earbuds and headphones, you can easily damage your hearing.

When the rest of the world gets too distracting, it’s tempting to pop in your earbuds, crank up your favourite tunes, and close yourself off to focus better.

If you consistently blast your music too loudly, you can damage your hearing. But it’s not just your ears: Hearing loss in older adults is linked to brain problems, such as Alzheimer’s and loss of brain tissue.
When your brain has to work so hard to understand what’s being said around you, it can’t store what you’ve heard into memory. So, protect your hearing by adjusting the volume of your headphones — it’s an excellent way to preserve your hearing and allow your brain to work better.

“One test we recommend is to remove your headphones, keeping them at your preferred volume, and hold them out in front of you at an arm’s length. Can you hear the music clearly? If so, try turning it down and repeating again,” writes Headphonesty. Always aim to take regular breaks during the course of the day to give your ears a much-needed rest.

Sleeping poorly upsets your brain

Insufficient sleep is a huge problem for many busy professionals. Sleep deprivation can have serious short-term and long-term consequences — it can delay reaction times, glucose levels, mood, headache, impaired memory, and hormone imbalances. Recent research shows that not getting enough sleep may actually shrink your brain.

Sleep is absolutely essential for your brain. When you deprive your brain healthy sleep, how it process information, consolidates memories, make connections, and clear out toxins suffers.

Lack of sleep slows down your thinking, impairs your memory, concentration, judgment, and decision-making, and impedes learning.
Improving your sleep habits could be an important way to improve brain health. 7–8 hours/night of good sleep is essential for stimulating new connections and brain growth.

If you are concerned about the health of your brain and the quality of your thinking now or in the future, learn to take care of your brain. A few simple changes to your lifestyle could boost your memory, learning, mental resilience and overall health of your brain.

[Cov(X,Y)]2⩽σX2σY2[Cov(X,Y)]^2\leqslant \sigma_X^2\sigma_Y^2 [Cov(X,Y)]2⩽σX2​σY2​

相关系数的性质

  1. −1⩽Corr(X,Y)⩽1-1\leqslant Corr(X,Y)\leqslant 1−1⩽Corr(X,Y)⩽1
  2. Corr(X,Y)=±1Corr(X,Y)=\pm 1Corr(X,Y)=±1的充要条件是XXX与YYY间几乎处处有线性关系，即存在a(≠0),ba(\neq 0),ba(​=0),b使得P(Y=aX+b)=1P(Y=aX+b)=1P(Y=aX+b)=1，其中当Corr(X,Y)=1Corr(X,Y)=1Corr(X,Y)=1时，有a>0a>0a>0;当Corr(X,Y)=−1Corr(X,Y)=-1Corr(X,Y)=−1时，有a<0a<0a<0。
  3. 在二维正态分布场合，不相关和独立是等价的。
  • 当Corr(X,X)=0Corr(X,X)=0Corr(X,X)=0时，称XXX与YYY不相关，这时XXX与YYY没有线性关系，但可能有其他函数关系。
  • 当Corr(X,X)=1Corr(X,X)=1Corr(X,X)=1时，称XXX与YYY完全正相关；当Corr(X,X)=−1Corr(X,X)=-1Corr(X,X)=−1时，称XXX与YYY完全负相关。
  • 当0<∣Corr(X,X)∣<10< |Corr(X,X)| <10<∣Corr(X,X)∣<1时，称XXX与YYY一定程度上相关。∣Corr(X,X)∣|Corr(X,X)|∣Corr(X,X)∣越接近1，则线性相关程度越高。∣Corr(X,X)∣|Corr(X,X)|∣Corr(X,X)∣越接近0，则线性相关程度越低。

注意：独立一定不相关，不相关则不一定独立。独立是两个变量没有任何关系，不相关是两个变量没有线性关系。

随机向量的数学期望向量与协方差矩阵

定义：记nnn维随机向量为X=(X1,X2,…,Xn)′\boldsymbol X=(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_n)'X=(X1​,X2​,…,Xn​)′，若其每个分量的数学期望都存在，则称

E(X)=(E(X1),E(X2),…,E(Xn))′E(\boldsymbol X)=(E(X_1),E(X_2),\dots,E(X_n))' E(X)=(E(X1​),E(X2​),…,E(Xn​))′

为n维随机变量或随机向量的数学期望向量，而称

E[(X−E(X))(X−E(X))′]=[Var(X1)Cov(X1,X2)…Cov(X1,Xn)Cov(X2,X1)Var(X2)…Cov(X2,Xn)⋮⋮⋱⋮Cov(Xn,X1)Cov(Xn,X2)…Var(Xn)]\begin{aligned} &E[(\boldsymbol X-E(\boldsymbol X))(\boldsymbol X-E(\boldsymbol X))']\\ &=\begin{bmatrix} Var(X_1)&Cov(X_1,X_2)&\dots&Cov(X_1,X_n)\\ Cov(X_2,X_1)&Var(X_2)&\dots&Cov(X_2,X_n)\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ Cov(X_n,X_1)&Cov(X_n,X_2)&\dots&Var(X_n)\\ \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}​E[(X−E(X))(X−E(X))′]=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​Var(X1​)Cov(X2​,X1​)⋮Cov(Xn​,X1​)​Cov(X1​,X2​)Var(X2​)⋮Cov(Xn​,X2​)​……⋱…​Cov(X1​,Xn​)Cov(X2​,Xn​)⋮Var(Xn​)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

为该随机向量的方差-协方差矩阵，简称协方差阵，记为Cov(X)Cov(\boldsymbol X)Cov(X)。

定理：nnn维随机向量的协方差阵Cov(X)=(Cov(Xi,Xj))n×nCov(\boldsymbol X)=(Cov(X_i,X_j))_{n\times n}Cov(X)=(Cov(Xi​,Xj​))n×n​是一个对称的非负定矩阵。

nnn元正态分布

记nnn维随机向量X=(X1,X2,…,Xn)′\boldsymbol X=(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_n)'X=(X1​,X2​,…,Xn​)′的协方差矩阵为B=Cov(X)\boldsymbol B=Cov(\boldsymbol X)B=Cov(X)，数学期望向量为a=(a1,a2,…,an)′\boldsymbol a=(a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n)'a=(a1​,a2​,…,an​)′。又记x=(x1,x2,…,xn)′\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)'x=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)′，则由密度函数

p(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)=p(x)=1(2π)n2∣B∣12exp⁡{−12(x−a)′B−1(x−a)}p\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=p(x)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{\frac{n}{2}}|B|^{\frac{1}{2}}} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2}(x-a)^{\prime} B^{-1}(x-a)\right\} p(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​)=p(x)=(2π)2n​∣B∣21​1​exp{−21​(x−a)′B−1(x−a)}

定义的正态分布称为nnn元正态分布，记为X∼N(a,B)\boldsymbol X\sim N(a,\boldsymbol B)X∼N(a,B).其中，∣B∣|\boldsymbol B|∣B∣表示B\boldsymbol BB的行列式，B−1\boldsymbol B^{-1}B−1表示逆矩阵，(x−a)′(\boldsymbol x-\boldsymbol a)'(x−a)′表示向量(x−a)(\boldsymbol x-\boldsymbol a)(x−a)的转置。
若记B−1=(rij)\boldsymbol B^{-1}=(r_{ij})B−1=(rij​)，则上式等价于

p(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)=1(2π)n2∣B∣12exp⁡{−12∑i,j=1nrij(xi−ai)(xj−aj)}p\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{\frac{n}{2}}|\boldsymbol{B}|^{\frac{1}{2}}} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{n} r_{i j}\left(x_{i}-a_{i}\right)\left(x_{j}-a_{j}\right)\right\} p(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​)=(2π)2n​∣B∣21​1​exp{−21​i,j=1∑n​rij​(xi​−ai​)(xj​−aj​)}

在n=2n=2n=2的场合，若取数学期望向量和协方差矩阵分别为

a=(μ1μ2),B=(σ12σ1σ2ρσ1σ2ρσ22)\boldsymbol{a}=\left(\begin{array}{l} \mu_{1} \\ \mu_{2} \end{array}\right), \quad \boldsymbol{B}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} \sigma_{1}^{2} & {\sigma}_ {1} {\sigma}_{2} {\rho} \\ {\sigma}_ {1} {\sigma}_ {2} {\rho} & {\sigma}_{2}^{2} \end{array}\right)a=(μ1​μ2​​),B=(σ12​σ1​σ2​ρ​σ1​σ2​ρσ22​​)

代入上式可得到二元正态密度函数。

条件分布与条件期望

离散随机变量的条件分布

设二维随机变量(X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y)的联合分布列为

pij=P(X=xi,Y=yi),i=1,2,…p_{ij}=P(X=x_i,Y=y_i),i=1,2,\dots pij​=P(X=xi​,Y=yi​),i=1,2,…

条件分布列的定义：对一切使得P(Y=yj)=p⋅j=∑i=1∞pij>0P(Y=y_j)=p_{\cdot j}=\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{\infin}p_{ij}>0P(Y=yj​)=p⋅j​=i=1∑∞​pij​>0的yjy_jyj​称

pi∣j=P(X=xi∣Y=yi)=P(X=xi,Y=yj)P(Y=yj)=pijp⋅j,i=1,2,…p_{i|j}=P(X=x_i|Y=y_i)=\frac {P(X=x_i,Y=y_j)}{P(Y=y_j)}=\frac {p_{ij}}{p_{\cdot j}},i=1,2,\dots pi∣j​=P(X=xi​∣Y=yi​)=P(Y=yj​)P(X=xi​,Y=yj​)​=p⋅j​pij​​,i=1,2,…

为给定Y=yjY=y_jY=yj​条件下的条件分布列。同理可得给定X=xiX=x_iX=xi​条件下的条件分布列。

条件分布函数的定义：给定Y=yjY=y_jY=yj​条件下的XXX的条件分布函数为

F(x∣yj)=∑xi⩽xP(X=xi,Y=yj)=∑xi⩽xpi∣jF(x|y_j)=\sum_{x_i\leqslant x}P(X=x_i,Y=y_j)=\sum_{x_i\leqslant x}p_{i|j} F(x∣yj​)=xi​⩽x∑​P(X=xi​,Y=yj​)=xi​⩽x∑​pi∣j​

给定X=xiX=x_iX=xi​条件下的条件分布函数类似。

连续随机变量的条件分布

设二维连续随机变量(X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y)的联合密度函数为p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y)，边际密度函数为pX(x),pY(y)p_X(x),p_Y(y)pX​(x),pY​(y)

定义：对一切使得pY(y)>0p_Y(y)>0pY​(y)>0的yyy，给定Y=yY=yY=y条件下XXX的条件分布函数和条件密度函数分别为

F(x∣y)=∫−∞xp(u,y)pY(y)dup(x∣y)=p(x,y)pY(y)\begin{aligned} &F(x|y)=\int_{-\infin}^{x}\frac {p(u,y)}{p_Y(y)}du\\ &p(x|y)=\frac {p(x,y)}{p_Y(y)} \end{aligned}​F(x∣y)=∫−∞x​pY​(y)p(u,y)​dup(x∣y)=pY​(y)p(x,y)​​

同理，对一切使得pX(x)>0p_X(x)>0pX​(x)>0的xxx，给定X=xX=xX=x条件下YYY的条件分布函数和条件密度函数分别为

F(y∣x)=∫−∞xp(v,x)pX(x)dvp(y∣x)=p(x,y)pX(x)\begin{aligned} &F(y|x)=\int_{-\infin}^{x}\frac {p(v,x)}{p_X(x)}dv\\ &p(y|x)=\frac {p(x,y)}{p_X(x)} \end{aligned}​F(y∣x)=∫−∞x​pX​(x)p(v,x)​dvp(y∣x)=pX​(x)p(x,y)​​

连续场合的全概率公式和贝叶斯公式

全概率公式：

pY(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)dx=∫−∞∞pX(x)⋅p(y∣x)dxpX(x)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)dy=∫−∞∞pY(y)⋅p(x∣y)dy\begin{aligned} p_Y(y)=\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}p(x,y)dx=\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}p_X(x)\cdot p(y|x)dx\\ p_X(x)=\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}p(x,y)dy=\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}p_Y(y)\cdot p(x|y)dy \end{aligned}pY​(y)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)dx=∫−∞∞​pX​(x)⋅p(y∣x)dxpX​(x)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)dy=∫−∞∞​pY​(y)⋅p(x∣y)dy​

贝叶斯公式：

p(x∣y)=pX(x)p(y∣x)∫−∞∞pX(x)p(y∣x)dxp(x|y)=\frac {p_X(x)p(y|x)}{\displaystyle\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}p_X(x)p(y|x)dx} p(x∣y)=∫−∞∞​pX​(x)p(y∣x)dxpX​(x)p(y∣x)​

另一种形式略。

条件数学期望

条件分布的数学期望称为条件期望，定义为

E(X∣Y=y)={∑ixiP(X=xi∣Y=y),(X,Y)为二维离散随机变量∫−∞∞xp(x∣y)dx,(X,Y)为二维连续随机变量\begin{aligned} E(X|Y=y)= \begin{cases} \displaystyle\sum_ix_iP(X=x_i|Y=y),&(X,Y)\text{为二维离散随机变量}\\ \displaystyle\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}xp(x|y)dx,&(X,Y)\text{为二维连续随机变量} \end{cases} \end{aligned}E(X∣Y=y)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​i∑​xi​P(X=xi​∣Y=y),∫−∞∞​xp(x∣y)dx,​(X,Y)为二维离散随机变量(X,Y)为二维连续随机变量​​

注意：条件期望E(X∣Y=y)E(X|Y=y)E(X∣Y=y)是yyy的函数。
例如：设XXX为中国成年人的身高，YYY为中国成年人的足长，则E(X∣Y=y)E(X|Y=y)E(X∣Y=y)表示足长为yyy的中国成年人的平均身高，我国公安部们研究获得E(X∣Y=y)=6.876yE(X|Y=y)=6.876yE(X∣Y=y)=6.876y

重期望公式

设(X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y)是二维连续随机变量，且E(X)E(X)E(X)存在，则

E(X)=E(E(X∣Y))E(X)=E(E(X|Y)) E(X)=E(E(X∣Y))

这里E(X∣Y)E(X|Y)E(X∣Y)本身也是一个随机变量。
例如：同上例，当Y取不同的值时，可求得不同足长的人的平均身高，再对这个平均身高求期望，就能得到中国人的平均身高。
实际应用这个公式，可以将一个大范围的问题分解为若干个小范围的问题来计算。也能解决一些用普通方法无法解决的问题。

例题

矿井里有一个矿工，三个门，走第一个3h可到安全区，走第二个5h后回到原地，走第三道7h后回到原地，假设矿工每次都等可能的选择三个门中的一个，求矿工到达安全区的平均用时。

解：设矿工需要X小时到达安全区，则X的可能取值有无数个，所以无法直接求E(X)。为此，记Y为第一次所选的第i个门，则有

P(Y=1)=P(Y=2)=P(Y=3)=13E(X∣Y=1)=3E(X∣Y=2)=5+E(X)E(X∣Y=3)=7+E(X)综上，可得E(X)=13[3+5+E(X)+7+E(X)]E(X)=15\begin{aligned} &P(Y=1)=P(Y=2)=P(Y=3)=\dfrac 13\\ &E(X|Y=1)=3\\ &E(X|Y=2)=5+E(X)\\ &E(X|Y=3)=7+E(X)\\ \text{综上，可得}\\ &E(X)=\dfrac 13[3 + 5 + E(X) + 7 + E(X)]\\ &E(X)=15 \end{aligned}综上，可得​P(Y=1)=P(Y=2)=P(Y=3)=31​E(X∣Y=1)=3E(X∣Y=2)=5+E(X)E(X∣Y=3)=7+E(X)E(X)=31​[3+5+E(X)+7+E(X)]E(X)=15​

随机个随机变量和的数学期望
设X1,X2,…,XnX_1,X_2,\dots,X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​为一系列独立同分布的随机变量，随机变量NNN只取正整数，且NNN与{Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}独立，则

E(∑i=1NXi)=E(X1)E(N)E(\sum_{i=1}^{N}X_i)=E(X_1)E(N) E(i=1∑N​Xi​)=E(X1​)E(N)

例如：每次掷骰子得到的点数期望为216\dfrac {21}6621​，则掷nnn次骰子的期望为216n\dfrac {21}6n621​n。

entry.title: 随机变量及其分布
entry.content:
随机变量及其分布

随机变量

定义在样本空间Ω\OmegaΩ上的实值函数X=X(w)X=X \pod wX=X(w)称为随机变量。根据取值为有限个或可列个与否分为离散随机变量和连续随机变量。

分布函数

设XXX是一个随机变量，对任意实数xxx，称F(x)=P(X⩽x)F\pod x = P\pod {X\leqslant x}F(x)=P(X⩽x)为XXX的分布函数。且称XXX服从F(x)F\pod xF(x)，记为X∼F(x)X\sim F\pod xX∼F(x)。有时也可用FX(x)F_X (x)FX​(x)，表明是XXX的分布函数。
任一随机变量都有一个分布函数。

基本性质

  1. 单调性：F(x)F(x)F(x)是定义在整个实数轴(−∞,∞)(-\infin,\infin)(−∞,∞)上的单调非减函数，即对任意的x1<x2x_1< x_2x1​<x2​，有F(x1)⩽F(x2)F(x_1)\leqslant F(x_2)F(x1​)⩽F(x2​)
  2. 有界性：对任意的xxx，有0⩽F(x)⩽10 \leqslant F(x)\leqslant 10⩽F(x)⩽1，且

F(−∞)=lim⁡x→−∞F(x)=0F(∞)=lim⁡x→∞F(x)=1\begin{aligned} F(-\infin)=\lim_{x \to - \infin}F(x)=0\\ F(\infin)=\lim_{x \to \infin}F(x)=1 \end{aligned} F(−∞)=x→−∞lim​F(x)=0F(∞)=x→∞lim​F(x)=1​

  1. 右连续性：F(x)F(x)F(x)是xxx的右连续函数，即对任意的x0x_0x0​，有lim⁡x→x0+F(x)=F(x0)\displaystyle \lim_{x \to x_0^+}F(x)=F(x_0)x→x0+​lim​F(x)=F(x0​)，即F(x0+0)=F(x0)F(x_0+0)=F(x_0)F(x0​+0)=F(x0​)。

离散随机变量的概率分布列

设X是一个离散随机变量，如果XXX的所有可能取值是x1,x2,…,xn,…x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n,\dotsx1​,x2​,…,xn​,…，则称XXX取xix_ixi​的概率pi=p(xi)=P(X=xi),i=1,2,…,n,…p_i=p(x_i)=P(X=x_i),i=1,2,\dots,n,\dotspi​=p(xi​)=P(X=xi​),i=1,2,…,n,…为XXX的概率分布列或简称分布列，记为X∼{pi}X\sim \{p_i\}X∼{pi​}。
也可以用一个函数表示，称为概率质量函数(PMF,probability mass function).S为X可能取值的集合。

f(x)={P(X=x),x∈S0,x∉Sf(x)=\begin{cases} P(X=x),x\in S\\ 0,x\notin S \end{cases} f(x)={P(X=x),x∈S0,x∈/​S​

基本性质：非负性，正则性(概率的和为1)。

连续随机变量的概率密度函数(PDF,probability density function)

设随机变量XXX的分布函数为F(x)F(x)F(x)，如果存在是数轴上的一个非负可积函数p(x)p \pod xp(x)，使得对任意实数xxx 有

F(x)=∫−∞xp(t)dtF(x)=\int_{-\infin}^xp(t)dt F(x)=∫−∞x​p(t)dt

则称p(x)p(x)p(x)为XXX的概率密度函数，简称密度函数，或称密度。密度函数也要有非负性和正则性。

注意：

  1. 连续随机变量的分布函数一定是整个数轴上的连续函数，离散随机变量的分布函数总是右连续的阶梯函数。
  2. 离散随机变量在其可能取值的任一点上的概率恒为零。因为P(X=a)=∫aap(x)dx=0\displaystyle P(X=a)=\int_a^ap(x)dx=0P(X=a)=∫aa​p(x)dx=0
  3. 因此，在事件{a⩽X⩽b}\{a \leqslant X \leqslant b\}{a⩽X⩽b}中剔除任意等号，不影响其概率。

随机变量的数学期望

数学期望的定义

离散

设离散随机变量XXX的分布列为pi=P(X=xi),i=1,2,…,n,…p_i=P(X=x_i),i=1,2,\dots,n,\dotspi​=P(X=xi​),i=1,2,…,n,…如果

∑i=1∞∣xi∣p(xi)<∞,\sum_{i=1}^\infin|x_i|p(x_i)<\infin, i=1∑∞​∣xi​∣p(xi​)<∞,

则称

E(X)=∑i=1∞xip(xi)E(X)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infin}x_ip(x_i) E(X)=i=1∑∞​xi​p(xi​)

为随机变量XXX的数学期望，或该分布的数学期望，简称期望或均值。若级数∑k=1∞∣xk∣p(xk)\sum_{k=1}^\infin|x_k|p(x_k)∑k=1∞​∣xk​∣p(xk​)不收敛，则称XXX的数学期望不存在。

连续

设连续随机变量XXX的概率密度函数为p(x)p(x)p(x)。如果

∫−∞∞∣x∣p(x)dx<∞,\int_{-\infin}^\infin|x|p(x)dx<\infin, ∫−∞∞​∣x∣p(x)dx<∞,

则称

E(X)=∫−∞∞xp(x)dxE(X)=\int_{-\infin}^{\infin}xp(x)dx E(X)=∫−∞∞​xp(x)dx

entry.title: 随机事件及概率
entry.content:
基本概念

基本术语

  • 样本空间：随机现象的一切可能的结果的集合。记为Ω={w}\Omega=\{w\}Ω={w}。
    • 离散样本空间：样本点个数有限或可列。
    • 连续样本空间：样本点个数为不可列无限个。
  • 事件：随机现象中某些样本点的集合。
    • 基本事件：Ω\OmegaΩ中单个元素的子集
    • 必然事件：本身
    • 不可能事件：Ω\OmegaΩ的最小子集，即空集∅\varnothing∅。
  • 随机变量：表示随机现象结果的变量，通常用大写字母表示。
  • 互不相容：A和B没有相同的样本点。
  • 对立：A和B互为对立事件的充要条件为：A∩B=∅,A∪B=ΩA\cap B=\varnothing,A\cup B=\OmegaA∩B=∅,A∪B=Ω
  • 对立事件一定互不相容，互不相容事件不一定对立。
  • 事件的运算：并和对立是最基本的运算。
    • 差：A−B=AB‾A-B=A\overline{B}A−B=AB
    • 交: A∩B=A‾∪B‾‾A\cap B=\overline{\overline{A}\cup \overline{B}}A∩B=A∪B
  • 事件域：设Ω\OmegaΩ为一样本空间，F为Ω\OmegaΩ的某些子集所组成的集合。如果F满足
    1. Ω∈F\Omega \in FΩ∈F
    2. 若A∈FA\in FA∈F，则A‾∈F\overline A \in FA∈F
    3. 若An∈F,n=1,2,…A_n\in F,n=1,2, \dotsAn​∈F,n=1,2,…,则可列并⋃n=1∞An∈F\displaystyle\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infin}A_n\in Fn=1⋃∞​An​∈F
      则称F是一个事件域，又称σ\sigmaσ域。在概率论中又称(Ω,F)(\Omega,F)(Ω,F)为可测空间(有概率可言)。
      4.举例：若Ω={w1,w2,…,wn}\Omega=\{w_1,w_2,\dots,w_n\}Ω={w1​,w2​,…,wn​}，则F是由∅\varnothing∅,n个单元素集，(n2)\binom n2(2n​)个双元素集，(n3)2\binom n32(3n​)2个三元素集…和Ω\OmegaΩ组成的集合。共2n2^n2n个事件。
  • 分割：将Ω\OmegaΩ划分为n个互不相容的事件D1,D2,…,DnD_1,D_2,\dots,D_nD1​,D2​,…,Dn​的行动。记为D=D1,D2,…,DnD =D_1,D_2,\dots,D_nD=D1​,D2​,…,Dn​，显然，诸DiD_iDi​互不相容，且⋃i=1nDi=Ω\displaystyle\bigcup_{i=1}^n D_i=\Omegai=1⋃n​Di​=Ω。

概率的定义及确定方法

定义

设Ω\OmegaΩ为一样本空间，F为Ω\OmegaΩ的一个事件域。如果对任一事件A∈FA\in FA∈F，定义一个在F上的是指函数P(A)，满足：

  1. 非负性公理：若A∈FA\in FA∈F，则P(A)⩾0P(A)\geqslant 0P(A)⩾0。
  2. 正则性公理：P(Ω)=1P(\Omega)=1P(Ω)=1
  3. 可列可加性公理：若A1,A2,…,AnA_1,A_2,\dots,A_nA1​,A2​,…,An​互不相容，则P(⋃i=1nAi=∑i=1nP(Ai))P(\displaystyle\bigcup_{i=1}^nA_i=\sum_{i=1}^n P(A_i))P(i=1⋃n​Ai​=i=1∑n​P(Ai​))。

其中P(A)称A的概率，(Ω,F,P)(\Omega,F,P)(Ω,F,P)为概率空间。

频率

  1. 与A有关的随机现象可大量重复进行。
  2. n(A)为A出现的频数，f⁡n(A)=n(A)n\operatorname {f}_n(A)=\displaystyle\frac {n(A)}{n}fn​(A)=nn(A)​
  3. 当n足够大时，频率会稳定在某个常数a附近，即概率(只是近似)。

古典概型

  1. 所涉及的随机现象有限。
  2. 每个样本点发生的可能性相同。
  3. 若A有k个样本点，则P(A)=knP(A)=\displaystyle\frac {k}{n}P(A)=nk​

几何概型

  1. 如果一个随机现象的样本空间Ω\OmegaΩ充满某个区域，其大小记为SΩS_{\Omega}SΩ​
  2. 任意一点落在度量相同的子区域内是等可能的。
  3. 若A为Ω\OmegaΩ中的某个子区域，度量为SAS_ASA​则，P(A)=SASΩP(A)= \displaystyle\frac {S_A}{S_\Omega}P(A)=SΩ​SA​​

注：度量一般为面积或体积。

蒙特卡罗法(Monte Carlo)–随机模拟法

设计一个随机试验，是一个事件的概率与某个未知数有关，然后通过随机试验，用频率估计概率，即可求得未知数的近似值。一般，实验次数越多，结果越精确。

如：蒲丰投针问题
平面上画有间隔为d(d>0)d(d>0)d(d>0)的等距平行线，向平面任意投掷一枚长为l(l<d)l(l< d)l(l<d)的针，求针与任一平行线相交的概率。

解：以xxx表示针的中点与最近的一条平行线的距离，以φ\varphiφ表示针与线的夹角。
易知：样本空间Ω\OmegaΩ满足 0⩽x⩽d/2,0⩽φ⩽π0 \leqslant x \leqslant d/2, 0 \leqslant \varphi \leqslant \pi0⩽x⩽d/2,0⩽φ⩽π
针与平行线相交(记为事件A)的充要条件为x⩽l2sin⁡φx \leqslant \frac l2 \sin \varphix⩽2l​sinφ。

P(A)=SASΩ=∫oπl2sin⁡φdφd2π=2ldπ≈nNP(A)=\frac {S_A}{S_\Omega}=\frac {\int_o^\pi \frac l2 \sin \varphi d\varphi}{\frac d2 \pi}=\frac {2l}{d\pi}\approx \frac nN P(A)=SΩ​SA​​=2d​π∫oπ​2l​sinφdφ​=dπ2l​≈Nn​

编程估算PI

试验：任取边长为2的正方形内的一点，求该点在正方形的内切圆内的概率。
易知：P(A)=ScircleSsquare=π4≈nNP(A)=\displaystyle\frac {S_{circle}}{S_{square}}=\frac {\pi}{4} \approx \frac nNP(A)=Ssquare​Scircle​​=4π​≈Nn​

贝特朗(Bertrand)悖论

在圆内任取一条弦，其长度超过该圆的内接等边三角形边长的概率是多少？

解一：做一条直径，显然只有交直径与1/4和3/4之间的弦符合要求。如此概率应为1/2。
解二：让弦一端端点固定，另一端点在圆上随机移动，在固定端点处作一切线，则与切线交角在60°∼120°60\degree \sim 120 \degree60°∼120°之间的角符合要求。如此，概率应为1/3。
解三：圆内切弦的位置由其中点唯一确定。在圆内作一个半径为r/2的同心圆，则大圆内弦的中点在小圆内，此弦才符合要求。如此，概率应为1/4。

不同解法结果不同的原因是他们的样本空间不同。
解一：Ω\OmegaΩ是直径上的点。
解二：Ω\OmegaΩ是圆周上的点。
解三：Ω\OmegaΩ是圆内所有的点。

启示：定义概率是要明确指出样本空间是什么。

概率的性质

事件的运算性质

  • 结合律：(AB)C=A(BC),(A∪B)∪C=A∪(B∪C)(AB)C=A(BC),(A\cup B)\cup C=A\cup (B\cup C)(AB)C=A(BC),(A∪B)∪C=A∪(B∪C)
  • 分配律：(A∪B)∩C=AC∪BC,(A∩B)∪C=(A∪C)∩(B∪C)(A\cup B)\cap C=AC\cup BC, (A\cap B)\cup C=(A\cup C)\cap (B\cup C)(A∪B)∩C=AC∪BC,(A∩B)∪C=(A∪C)∩(B∪C)
  • 对偶律(德摩根公式)：A∪B‾=A‾∩B‾,A∩B‾=A‾∪B‾\overline{A \cup B}=\overline A \cap \overline B, \overline{A \cap B}=\overline A \cup \overline BA∪B=A∩B,A∩B=A∪B

运算性质

  • P(∅)=0P(\varnothing)=0P(∅)=0。不可能事件的概率为0，但概率为0的事件不一定是不可能事件。如取(0,1)中任一点的概率都为0。
  • 可加性：若有限个事件不相容，则有P(⋃i=1nAi)=∑i=1nP(Ai)P(\displaystyle\bigcup_{i=1}^nA_i)=\sum_{i=1}^nP(A_i)P(i=1⋃n​Ai​)=i=1∑n​P(Ai​)
  • P(A)=1−P(A‾)P(A)=1-P(\overline A)P(A)=1−P(A)
  • 若A⊃BA \supset BA⊃B，则P(A−B)=P(A)−P(B)P(A-B)=P(A)-P(B)P(A−B)=P(A)−P(B)。
  • P(A−B)=P(A)−P(AB)P(A-B)=P(A)-P(AB)P(A−B)=P(A)−P(AB)
  • 加法公式：P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(AB)⩽P(A)+P(B)P(A \cup B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(AB) \leqslant P(A)+P(B)P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(AB)⩽P(A)+P(B)

条件概率

条件概率定义

设A与B是样本空间Ω\OmegaΩ中的两个事件，若P(B)>0P(B)>0P(B)>0，则称P(A∣B)=P(AB)P(B)P(A|B)=\frac {P(AB)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(AB)​为在B发生时，A的条件概率。

乘法公式

  1. 若P(B)>0P(B)>0P(B)>0，则P(AB)=P(B)⋅P(A∣B)P(AB)=P(B)\cdot P(A|B)P(AB)=P(B)⋅P(A∣B)
  2. 若P(A1A2…An)>0P(A_1A_2\dots A_n)>0P(A1​A2​…An​)>0，则P(A1A2…An)=P(A1)⋅P(A2∣A1)⋅P(A3∣A1A2)…P(An∣A1…An−1)P(A_1A_2\dots A_n)=P(A_1)\cdot P(A_2|A_1)\cdot P(A_3|A_1A_2)\dots P(A_n|A_1\dots A_{n-1})P(A1​A2​…An​)=P(A1​)⋅P(A2​∣A1​)⋅P(A3​∣A1​A2​)…P(An​∣A1​…An−1​)

全概率公式

设B1,B2,…,BnB_1,B_2,\dots,B_nB1​,B2​,…,Bn​为样本空间的一个分割(或B1,B2,…,BnB_1,B_2,\dots,B_nB1​,B2​,…,Bn​互不相容，且A⊂⋃i=1nBiA \subset \displaystyle\bigcup_{i=1}^nB_iA⊂i=1⋃n​Bi​)，如果P(Bi)>0,i=1,2,…,nP(B_i)>0,i=1,2,\dots,nP(Bi​)>0,i=1,2,…,n，则对任一事件A有

P(A)=∑i=1nP(Bi)P(A∣Bi)P(A)=\sum_{i=1}^nP(B_i)P(A|B_i) P(A)=i=1∑n​P(Bi​)P(A∣Bi​)

贝叶斯公式

设B1,B2,…,BnB_1,B_2,\dots,B_nB1​,B2​,…,Bn​为样本空间的一个分割，如果P(A)>0,P(Bi)>0,i=1,2,…,nP(A)>0,P(B_i)>0,i=1,2,\dots,nP(A)>0,P(Bi​)>0,i=1,2,…,n，则

P(Bi∣A)=P(Bi)P(A∣Bi)∑j=1nP(Bj)P(A∣Bj)P(B_i|A)=\frac {P(B_i)P(A|B_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^nP(B_j)P(A|B_j)} P(Bi​∣A)=∑j=1n​P(Bj​)P(A∣Bj​)P(Bi​)P(A∣Bi​)​

其中，如果称P(Bi)P(B_i)P(Bi​)为BiB_iBi​的先验概率，称P(Bi∣A)P(B_i|A)P(Bi​∣A)为BiB_iBi​的后验概率，则贝叶斯公式是专门用来计算后验概率的，也就是通过A的发生这个新的信息，来对BiB_iBi​的概率作出的修正。

独立性

如果P(AB)=P(A)P(B)P(AB)=P(A)P(B)P(AB)=P(A)P(B)，则称事件A和B相互独立。
注意：若A与B独立，则AAA与B‾\overline BB,A‾\overline AA与BBB，A‾\overline AA与B‾\overline BB独立。

对于n个事件A1,A2,…,AnA_1,A_2,\dots,A_nA1​,A2​,…,An​，对任意的1⩽i⩽j⩽k⩽n1\leqslant i \leqslant j \leqslant k \leqslant n1⩽i⩽j⩽k⩽n，若有

P(AiAj)=P(Ai)P(Aj)P(AiAjAk)=P(Ai)P(Aj)P(Ak)⋮P(AiAj…An)=P(Ai)P(Aj)…P(An)\begin{aligned} P(A_iA_j)&=P(A_i)P(A_j)\\ P(A_iA_jA_k)&=P(A_i)P(A_j)P(A_k)\\ &\enspace \vdots\\ P(A_iA_j\dots A_n)&=P(A_i)P(A_j)\dots P(A_n) \end{aligned}P(Ai​Aj​)P(Ai​Aj​Ak​)P(Ai​Aj​…An​)​=P(Ai​)P(Aj​)=P(Ai​)P(Aj​)P(Ak​)⋮=P(Ai​)P(Aj​)…P(An​)​

则称n个事件相互独立。

试验的独立性

如果试验E1,E2,…,EnE_1,E_2,\dots,E_nE1​,E2​,…,En​的结果是相互独立的，则称E1,E2,…,EnE_1,E_2,\dots,E_nE1​,E2​,…,En​相互独立。
如果这n个试验还是相同的，则称n重独立重复试验。
如果这n个试验可能的结果都为2个AAA或A‾\overline AA，则称为n重伯努利试验。

entry.content:
基本概念

  • 排序的确切定义：
    • 输入：n个记录R1,R2,…,RnR_1,R_2,\dots,R_nR1​,R2​,…,Rn​,对应关键字为k1,k2,…,knk_1,k_2,\dots,k_nk1​,k2​,…,kn​。
    • 输出：输入记录的一个重排R1′,R2′,…,Rn′R_1',R_2',\dots,R_n'R1′​,R2′​,…,Rn′​,使得k1′≤k2′≤⋯≤kn′k_1' \le k_2' \le \dots \le k_n'k1′​≤k2′​≤⋯≤kn′​。
  • 算法的稳定性：排序前后，同key元素能否保持相对位置关系不变。(3,2,2*,1 => 1,2,2*,3就是稳定的，若可能排成1,2*,2,3则称为不稳定)
  • 内部排序：排序过程中，数据元素完全在内存中。
  • 排序的时间复杂度一般靠比较和移动次数来确定。

插入排序

基本思想：每次将一个待排序的记录插入到前面已排好序的子序列中。

直接插入排序

折半插入排序

基本思想：直接插入排序时，查找插入位置和移动元素是同时进行的，比较和移动次数都是O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)。可以将查找插入位置和移动元素分开，则比较次数可以降至O(nlogn)O(nlogn)O(nlogn)，但移动次数不变，总复杂度仍是O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)。

希尔排序

基本思想：插入排序对基本有序的表排序效率较高。所以，将要排序的列表看成两个子列表，每个子列表对应位置的元素可看作一个更小的列表，对这个更小的列表插入排序。排完后，在将两个子列表分成四个，再次插入排序。以此类推。相当于8个元素的列表，先从第1个元素开始，隔4个元素为一组，各自排序((15),(26),(37),(48))，再隔2个元素为一组，各自排序((1357),(2468))…
看上去更复杂了，但因为有序的列表排序需要的操作更少，实际上时间复杂度有所下降。

交换排序

基本思想：比较两个元素的key，根据比较结果决定是否交换位置。

冒泡排序

基本思想：从前往后两两比较相邻元素的值，如果是逆序(前一个元素比后一个大)则交换位置，直到比较完整个序列，称为一趟冒泡。下一趟，已经排序好的元素就不参加了。这样，最多n-1趟就能排好序。

快速排序

基本思想：在表中取一个元素pivot，以pivot为基准，将表划分为独立的两部分，一部分中任意元素都小于pivot，另一部分大于。pivot位于两子表之间的位置。这个过程称为一趟快速排序。而后，对两个子表递归的重复这个过程，直到表中只有一个元素或为空。排序完成。

选择排序

基本思想：每一趟选一个最小的元素放在未排序的表最靠左位置(或最大，靠右)。重复n-1趟就能排好序。

简单选择排序

堆排序

基本思想：将表视为一棵完全二叉树。用完全二叉树中父节点和子节点的关系，每次选出一个最大值(或最小值)。

堆的定义：n个元素序列称为堆，当且仅当任意父节点都比子节点大(或小)，也称为大跟堆(小根堆)。

归并排序

基本思想：假定有一个n个记录的表待排序。则可将其视为n个有序的子表，每个子表长度为1。然后两两归并，得到⌈n/2⌉\lceil n/2 \rceil⌈n/2⌉个子表，再两两归并…如此重复，直到合并为一个长度为n的有序表为止。

分配排序

桶式排序

基本思想：假设待排序序列为某区间上均匀分布的一个随机序列。将区间划分为n个等长的子区间(称为箱)。然后将每个桶内的元素排好序，依次输出各个桶内的元素，就得到排好序的序列了。

复杂度：如果每个桶都使用插入排序，则总复杂度为T(n)=O(n)+∑i=1nO(n2)T(n)=O(n)+\sum_{i=1}^nO(n^2)T(n)=O(n)+∑i=1n​O(n2)。可以证明整个桶式排序的时间复杂度为O(n)O(n)O(n)。

基数排序

基本概念：

  • 排序码：用于排序的数据项。如：扑克牌有两个排序码，花色和数值。
  • 多排序码有序：假定有一个n个元素的表V0,V1…,Vn{V_0,V_1 \dots, V_n}V0​,V1​…,Vn​,且每个元素中都含有d个排序码(Ki1,Ki2,…,KidK_i^1,K_i^2, \dots , K_i^dKi1​,Ki2​,…,Kid​)。如果表中任意两个元素ViV_iVi​,VjV_jVj​都满足:(Ki1,Ki2,…,Kid)<(Kj1,Kj2,…,Kjd)(K_i^1,K_i^2, \dots , K_i^d)<(K_j^1,K_j^2, \dots , K_j^d)(Ki1​,Ki2​,…,Kid​)<(Kj1​,Kj2​,…,Kjd​)。则称为有序。其中Ki1K_i^1Ki1​为最高位排序码，KidK_i^dKid​为最低位排序码。
  • 多排序码排序：分为最高位优先MSD和最低位优先LSD。
  • 基数排序：用多排序码排序实现对单个排序码排序的算法。即将单个排序码看作一组子排序码。

MSD(Most Significant Digit first)

例：有一组元素，排序码为0 ~ 999间的数字。我们可以把这个排序码看作个位，十位，百位三个子排序码的组和。每个数据在各位上可能的取值都是0 ~ 9，共10种可能，称为基数 radix。
排序过程中，先根据百位上的数字排序，并按值分配到相应的子序列(称为桶)中，再按桶的编号逐个进行递归的MSD排序。

一般来说，基数越大，子序列规模越小，排序效率越高。但是，如果基数较大，可能出现很多空接受器，空接受器的大量存在会严重影响基数排序的效率。

LSD(Least Significant Digit first)

LSD使用排序码的顺序和MSD相反，从最低位排序码开始。这种方式不需要分组，只需要"分配"和"收集"。
分配：将元素按排序码分配到相应的桶中。
收集：按桶的编号将元素逐个取出。

排序算法的比较

最小生成树(Minimum-Spanning-Tree, MST)

定义和性质

生成树：图的无环的，包含所有顶点的子图。
最小生成树：带权图的权值最小的生成树。

树的相关性质

  1. 给树的任意两个节点添加一条边，则得到一个环。
  2. 从树种删去任意一条边，则得到两个子树。

Cut property

a cut of graph:将图的顶点集分割为两个。
crossing edge:分割顶点时切到的边。

Cut property:任何图的一个cut，对应的crossing edge中最小的一定在MST中。
Proof：假设图的MST，T中的一条边，不是图的某一个cut，对应的最小的crossing edge，e，而包含了必定更大的crossing edge ，f，那么把f删除，加上e，得到的MST必然比T小。这和T是MST矛盾。(设图是联通的且不考虑有边权值相等或有权值为负数的情况)

贪心策略求MST

设定每找到一条最小的crossing edge，就将其标记。
任意cut一个图，标记一条最小的crossing edge。再不涉及已标记的边的前提下，再次cut，再标记一条边，如此反复，直到不能再cut(即标记了n-1条边)。

Prim算法

从图的一个顶点开始，将该顶点视为一棵单节点的树，然后添加n-1条边，得到MST.添加的每一条边都需要满足两点，一，两个顶点一个在树上，另一个不在，二，是满足一的最小的边。

Kruskal算法

将图的边排序，从图的最小的边开始，每次都添加当前剩下的边中最小的，如果添加后会产生环的话，跳过这条边。添加了n-1条边后得到MST。

entry.title: 图
entry.content:
不同的"图"

  • paint: 笔刷画的油画
  • drawing: 用硬币画出来的画，素描，线条画
  • picture: 真实形象所反映的画，如照片
  • image: 由印象而来的画，或通过传感器印象出的影像
  • figure: 轮廓图
  • diagram: 抽象的概念关系图
  • chart: 统计图表
  • map: 地图
  • plot: 地图上的一小块
  • graph: 由一些 基本元素构造 而来的图，如点，线段等

图(Graph)的基本概念

图的定义

图由顶点集V和边集E组成，记为G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)，其中V(G)V(G)V(G)表示图G中顶点的有限非空集，E(G)E(G)E(G)表示图中顶点之间的关系集合。
用∣V∣|V|∣V∣表示图中的顶点个数，也称图的阶。
用∣E∣|E|∣E∣表示图中边的条数。

基本概念

图的类型

  • 无向图：E是无向边的有限集合时，图为无向图。边是顶点的无序对，记为(v,w)(v,w)(v,w)或(w,v)(w,v)(w,v)，二者等价。
  • 有向图：E是有向边的有限集合时，图为有向图。有向图中的边可称为弧，可记为<v,w><v,w><v,w>，读作从顶点v到顶点w的弧，也称v邻接到w或w邻接自v，其中v是弧头，w是弧尾。
  • 简单图：不存在重复边，也不存在自邻接的边。
  • 多重图：和简单图相对，存在重复边或自邻接的边的图。
  • 完全图：
    • 无向图：任意两个顶点之间都存在边。含n个顶点的无向完全图有n(n−1)2\frac {n(n-1)}22n(n−1)​条边。
    • 有向图：任意两个顶点之间都存在方向相反的两条弧。含n个顶点的有向完全图有n(n−1)n(n-1)n(n−1)条边。
  • 子图：设有两个图G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)和G′=(V′,E′)G'=(V',E')G′=(V′,E′)，若V′V'V′是VVV的子集且E′E'E′是EEE的子集，则称G′G'G′是GGG的子集
    • 并非任何V和E的子集都能构成子图，因为子集可能不是图。
    • 生成子图：满足V(G′)=V(G)V(G')=V(G)V(G′)=V(G)的子图G′G'G′。即具有GGG中所有顶点的子图。

连通

  • 连通：从顶点v到顶点w有路径存在，则称v和w是连通的。
  • 连通图：无向图中任意两个顶点之间都是连通的，则称该图为连通图。
  • 连通分量：无向图中的极大连通子图。
  • 强连通：从顶点v到顶点w，从顶点w到顶点v都有路径存在，则称v和w是连通的。
  • 强连通图，强连通分量：略。
  • 生成树：连通图的生成树是包含图中全部顶点的一个极小连通子图。
  • 生成森林：非连通图中，连通分量的生成树构成了非连通图的生成森林。

PS：极大连通要求子图包含其所有边，极小连通要求保持连通同时边数最小。

其他

  • 顶点的度(Degree)
    • 度：和顶点相连的边的条数。记为TD(v)TD(v)TD(v)，且有∑i=1nTD(vi)=2e\sum_{i=1}^nTD(v_i)=2e∑i=1n​TD(vi​)=2e。
    • 入度：有向图中顶点的入边条数。记为ID(v)ID(v)ID(v)。
    • 出度：记为OD(v)OD(v)OD(v)。且有TD(v)=ID(v)+OD(v)TD(v)=ID(v)+OD(v)TD(v)=ID(v)+OD(v)和∑i=1nID(vi)=∑i=1nOD(vi)=e\sum_{i=1}^nID(v_i)=\sum_{i=1}^nOD(v_i)=e∑i=1n​ID(vi​)=∑i=1n​OD(vi​)=e。
  • 边的权(Weight)：每条边上标的数值。边上有权的图又称为带权图或网。
  • 路径(Path)：由边依次连起来的顶点序列。路径长度为边的数量或边的权重之和。
  • 回路(Cycle)：首尾顶点相同的路径。
  • 简单路径和简单回路：没有重复顶点的路径和回路(除了首尾顶点)。
  • 距离：最短路径的长度。如果路径不存在，则记距离为无穷∞\infty∞
  • 有向树：一个顶点入度为0，其余顶点入度均为1的有向图。
  • 稠密图和稀疏图：是相对的概念。一般将∣E∣<∣V∣log⁡∣V∣|E|<|V|\log|V|∣E∣<∣V∣log∣V∣的图视为稀疏图。
  • 有向无环图(DAG,Directed Acyclic Graph): 不存在任何环的有向图，如树

图的存储及基本操作

邻接矩阵法

指用一个一维数组存储图中顶点的信息，用一个二维数组存储图中边的信息(即各顶点的邻接关系)，存储顶点之间邻接关系的二维数组称为邻接矩阵。节点数为n的图的邻接矩阵A是n×nn \times nn×n的。

普通图：

A[i][j]={1,(vi,vj)或<vi,vj>是E(G)中的边0,(vi,vj)或<vi,vj>不是E(G)中的边A[i][j]= \begin{cases} 1, & (v_i,v_j)\text{或}<v_i, v_j>\text{是$E(G)中的边$} \\ 0, & (v_i,v_j)\text{或}<v_i, v_j>\text{不是$E(G)中的边$} \end{cases} A[i][j]={1,0,​(vi​,vj​)或<vi​,vj​>是E(G)中的边(vi​,vj​)或<vi​,vj​>不是E(G)中的边​

带权图：

A[i][j]={wij,(vi,vj)或<vi,vj>是E(G)中的边0或∞,(vi,vj)或<vi,vj>不是E(G)中的边A[i][j]= \begin{cases} w_{ij}, & (v_i,v_j)\text{或}<v_i, v_j>\text{是$E(G)$中的边} \\ 0\text{或}\infty, & (v_i,v_j)\text{或}<v_i, v_j>\text{不是$E(G)$中的边} \end{cases} A[i][j]={wij​,0或∞,​(vi​,vj​)或<vi​,vj​>是E(G)中的边(vi​,vj​)或<vi​,vj​>不是E(G)中的边​

注意：

  • 在简单应用中，可直接用二维数组作为图的邻接矩阵。
  • 无向图的邻接矩阵是对称矩阵，对规模大的邻接矩阵可采用压缩存储。
  • 邻接矩阵的空间复杂的为O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)，其中n为图的顶点数。

特点：

  • 无向图的邻接矩阵是一定是对称矩阵。
  • 无向图的邻接矩阵的第i行(或列)非零元素的个数正好是第i个顶点的度。
  • 有向图的邻接矩阵的第i行(或列)非零元素的个数正好是第i个顶点的出度或入度。
  • 邻接矩阵存储图，容易找到任意两个顶点是否相连。但是，要确定有多少条边则必须遍历每行每列。
  • 设图的邻接矩阵为AAA，AnA^nAn的元素An[i][j]A^n[i][j]An[i][j]等于由顶点i到顶点j的长度为n的路径的数目。

邻接表法

指对图中的每个顶点viv_ivi​建立一个顺序存储的链表称为顶点表,顶点表中的每个元素都是存储了顶点数据(data)，并保存了指向viv_ivi​的第一条邻接边的指针(first_arc)。first_arc指向第一个边节点，边节点是一种新节点，含有一个保存终顶点位置的域(adjvex)和指向viv_ivi​下一个邻接边的指针(next_arc)。

特点：

  • 无向图的空间复杂度为O(∣V∣+2∣E∣)O(|V|+2|E|)O(∣V∣+2∣E∣)，有向图的空间复杂度为O(∣V∣+∣E∣)O(|V|+|E|)O(∣V∣+∣E∣)
  • 邻接表容易找出顶点的所有邻边，因为只要读取邻接表即可。但确定两个顶点是否相连，则需要遍历相应的边表，没邻接矩阵方便。
  • 有向图的邻接表容易找出度，不容易找入度。用逆邻接表则容易找入度不容易找出度。
  • 图的邻接表表示不唯一的，因为各边节点的链接次序可以是任意的。

十字链表和邻接多重表

对有向图来说，邻接链表可以方便的提供顶点和相应的出边或入边信息。十字链表同时保存了出边和入边的信息。

邻接多重表是无向图的另一种存储方式，邻接表容易找出顶点的所有邻边，但要判断两个顶点之间是否存在边并要删除边时，就需要分别遍历两个顶点的边表。

基本操作

  • Adjacent(G, x, y): 判断图是否存在边(x,y)或<x,y>。
  • Neighbors(G, x): 列出图中与节点x邻接的边
  • InsertVertex(G, x): 插入顶点
  • DeleteVertex(G, x)
  • AddEdge(G, x, y)
  • RemoveEdge(G, x, y)
  • FirstNeighbour(G, x)
  • NextNeighbour(G, x, y): 返回x的边(x,y)的下一条边的终顶点，没有就返回-1
  • 获取和设置边的权值
  • 遍历

图的遍历

广度优先搜索(Breadth-First-Search,BFS)

基本思想：类似树的层序遍历。首先，访问起始节点v，再从起始节点出发，访问v的所有邻接节点，再从访问过的邻接点开始，访问所有邻接点的未被访问过的邻接点。以此类推，直到访问完所有节点。

BFS

算法分析：

  1. 空间复杂度：BFS算法需要借助一个辅助队列Q，每个顶点都要入队一次，最坏情况下，空间复杂度为O(∣V∣)O(|V|)O(∣V∣)

  2. 时间复杂度：

    • 邻接矩阵：O(∣V∣2)O(|V|^2)O(∣V∣2)，每个顶点都要访问一次，每个顶点都要遍历相应的矩阵行来找相邻的边，V×O(V)V \times O(V)V×O(V)。
    • 邻接表：O(∣V∣+∣E∣)O(|V|+|E|)O(∣V∣+∣E∣)，每个顶点都要访问一次，找相邻的边需要把每个边也遍历一遍，故总共需要O(∣V∣)+O(∣E∣)O(|V|)+O(|E|)O(∣V∣)+O(∣E∣)

注意：对于同样一个图，基于邻接矩阵的遍历得到的BFS,DFS序列是唯一的，基于邻接表的遍历得到的BFS,DFS序列不是唯一的，因为图的邻接矩阵是唯一的而邻接表不是。

深度优先搜索(Depth-First-Search, DFS)

基本思想：类似树的先序遍历。首先，访问起始节点v，再从起始节点出发，访问与v邻接且未访问过的节点w1w_1w1​，再从访问过的邻接点w1w_1w1​开始，访问w1w_1w1​的邻接且未访问过的节点w2w_2w2​。以此类推，直到不能继续向下访问时，依次退回最近被访问的顶点，若它还有未被访问的节点，则从该点开始继续上述搜索。

DFS

算法分析：

  1. 空间复杂度：DFS需要借助一个递归工作栈，因此其空间复杂度为O(∣V∣)O(|V|)O(∣V∣)

  2. 时间复杂度同BFS

entry.title: GIT基本使用方法
entry.content:
版本控制

当你开发一个简单的小项目的时候，可能没几个文件，记住开发进度和上次修改了什么比较轻松。但是版本控制(tracking revisions over time,按时间追踪记录修改)会随着项目复杂化而更加复杂。

如果你不仅想追踪修改历史，还想知道是谁，什么时候修改的。就需要版本控制系统(Version Control System,VCS)。

VCS软件(以git为例)，通常包含以下工具：

  • 保存项目状态 (snapshot)
  • 查看修改历史 (git log)
  • 撤销修改 (git reset)
  • 防止冲突

git是当前最流行的版本控制工具，用a stream of snapshot记录修改，并且是分布式的。

github或coding.net是提供git仓库托管服务的。你可以将你本地的仓库推送到github,github中就有了和你本地仓库完全一样的库。在github上，有图形化界面可以方便的进行修改，合并等操作。

使用Git

初始化仓库(init repository)

首先，创建一个新文件夹，并进入该文件夹。或者进入一个已有的文件夹。
执行git init命令即可。
执行完之后，该文件夹下会出现一个.git文件夹。本地仓库初始化就成功了。

跟踪文件(tracking files)，提交(commit)，查看提交历史

库(即init的文件夹)中的文件有三种状态：

  • Not tracked:未跟踪，git不会记录这类文件的变化
  • Staged:暂存，变化已经记录到临时工作区(Staging Area)
  • Committed:已提交，记录修改确定了，git中记录的当前版本就是提交后的版本了

第一次提交时，需要设置用户名和邮箱地址。多人协作的必要步骤。

查看提交历史

修改最近一次提交(amend)

忠告：千万别对已经提交到远程仓库的commit进行amend。因为如果有其他人pull过了，会给远程仓库带来严重的混乱。

换了github账户后的提交错误

原账户userA,新账户userB。clone一个新账户的库，本地修改无法提交，报错：remote: Permission to userB/testa.git denied to userA。原因是userA账户生成了ssh key。userB 提交commit到GitHub时，用的是userA的对应的ssh公匙，所以会报这个错。
想要同时用两个账户，需要如下操作：

之后在c:/Users/yourusername/.ssh下创建config文件，文件名就叫config。输入以下内容:

之后再修改提交的GitHub远程库的ssh地址即可。

再次提交就没问题了。

克隆远程库(clone),拉取(pull)和推送(push)

在github上创建的仓库都有一个地址。可以选择https或ssh形式的。

Reset&Checkout

分支(branch)

Stash

git stash命令会暂时缓存任何你未提交的修改，包括暂存区的和未暂存的(没有通过git add命令添加到暂存区的，包括新add的增删文件，修改add过的文件)，不包括未追踪的文件。stash就相当于将之前的修改都隐藏了起来，之后的操作不会受到之前修改的限制。
注意：stash只保留在本地库中，不会被推送到远程库。

注意：git stash apply会将修改应用到所有分支。比如，在test分支修改了一个文件，stash以后再apply回来，这样master分支中也会有一个未提交的修改。

合并冲突

在合并分支，apply stash，pull，push时如果文件内容有冲突(即不同人/分支的不同提交中修改了相同的地方)。

解决冲突：首先用git status查看有冲突的文件，打开有冲突的文件，在有冲突的地方会有提示符。<<<<<<<, ========, 和>>>>>>>。一般 <<<<<<< 和 ======= 之间是接受合并的分支，另一半是被合入的分支。把冲突的地方改好后提交即可。

entry.title: 树
entry.content:
相关术语

  • 节点(Node)：树的基本组成部分，每个节点具有名称，并且可以保存额外的数据项。
  • 度数(Degree): 一个节点的子节点的个数称为该节点的度。
  • 边(Edge)： 树的另一个基本组成部分
    • 每条边恰好连接两个节点，表示节点之间的关联
    • 每个节点都有一条入边(除根节点)和多条出边(除叶节点)。
  • 路径(Path)：由边连接在一起的有序节点列表
  • 子树(subtree)：一个节点及其所有子孙节点和相关边的集合
  • 层级(level)：从根节点到达一个节点路径包含的边的数量
  • 高度：树的层级的最大值。根节点所在层数为1。
  • 森林：森林是m棵互不相交的树的集合。

定义及特点

树是n个节点的有限集合，n=0时，称为空树。在任意一棵非空树中应满足：

  • 有且只有一个根节点
  • 除根节点外，每个节点及其子孙节点又构成一棵树，即子树。

性质

  1. 树的结点树等于所有节点的度数加1
  2. 度为m的树中第i层至多有mi−1m^{i-1}mi−1个节点
  3. 高度为h的m叉树至多有(mh−1)/(m−1)(m^h-1)/(m-1)(mh−1)/(m−1)个节点
  4. 具有n个节点的m叉树的最小高度为[logm(n(m−1)+1)][log_m(n(m-1)+1)][logm​(n(m−1)+1)]
公式推导

(a−1)∑i=0nan=∑i=0n(an+1−an)=(a1−a0)+(a2−a1)+(a3−a2)+⋯+(an+1−an)=an+1−1∑i=0nan=an+1−1a−1\begin{aligned} (a-1)\sum_{i=0}^na^n&=\sum_{i=0}^n(a^{n+1}-a^n) \\ &=(a^1-a^0)+(a^2-a^1)+(a^3-a^2)+ \dots + (a^{n+1}-a^n) \\ &=a^{n+1}-1 \\ \sum_{i=0}^na^n&=\frac {a^{n+1}-1}{a-1} \end{aligned}(a−1)i=0∑n​ani=0∑n​an​=i=0∑n​(an+1−an)=(a1−a0)+(a2−a1)+(a3−a2)+⋯+(an+1−an)=an+1−1=a−1an+1−1​​

[logm(n(m−1)+1)][log_m(n(m-1)+1)][logm​(n(m−1)+1)]就是对mh−1m−1=n\frac {m^h-1}{m-1}=nm−1mh−1​=n移项再取对数。

二叉树

每个节点最多只有2个子节点，并且有左右之分，其次序不能任意颠倒。

和度为2的有序树的区别

  • 度为2的有序树至少有3个节点，而二叉树可以为空。
  • 度为2的有序树的次序是相对另一个子节点而言的，只有一个子节点时，就没有左右次序。而二叉树无论子节点是否为2，均需要确定其左右次序。

特殊的二叉树

满二叉树

高为h，且含有2h−12^h-12h−1个节点的二叉树，即每层都含有最多节点的树。

完全二叉树

每个节点都和满二叉树中编号1~n的节点一一对应的树。

特点：一个有n个节点的二叉树

  • 若i≤⌊n/2⌋i \le \lfloor n/2 \rfloori≤⌊n/2⌋，则为分支节点，否则为叶节点
  • 叶节点最多出现在底层和次底层
  • 每一个节点都有两个子节点(最多有一个例外，即最后一个叶子节点的父节点)
  • 只有一个左子节点的分支节点后面均为叶子节点
  • 若n为偶数，则最后一个节点是左子节点，其父节点只有一个子节点。若n为奇数，则每个分支节点都有左右子节点。

二叉树的性质

  1. 非空二叉树的叶子节点数等于度数为2的节点数加1。
  2. 非空二叉树第k层至多有2k−12^{k-1}2k−1个节点
  3. 高为h的二叉树至多有2h−12^{h}-12h−1个节点
  4. 如果某个节点下标为p，则其左子节点为2p，右子节点为2p+1，父节点为p//2。(不能超过树的总节点数)
  5. 节点p所在深度为⌊log2p⌋+1\lfloor log_2p \rfloor+1⌊log2​p⌋+1
性质1证明

设度为0，1，2的节点数为n0n_0n0​，n1n_1n1​，n2n_2n2​。则有n=n0+n1+n2n=n_0+n_1+n_2n=n0​+n1​+n2​。由上面二叉树的图可知，除了根节点，树的每一条边对对应一个节点，节点的度数即为边数，故有n=n1+2n2+1n=n_1+2n_2+1n=n1​+2n2​+1。结合两式可得：n0=n2+1n_0=n_2+1n0​=n2​+1

二叉树的存储结构

顺序存储

根据二叉树的性质，完全二叉树和满二叉树采用顺序存储比较好。用数组下标确定节点在二叉树中的位置(因为数组下标是从0开始的，处理起来不方便，所以可以让数组第一个位置空着，这样数组下标和元素序数就对应了)。

堆排序-python

链式存储

在含有n个节点的二叉链表中，含有n+1个空链域。(只有根节点时，有两个空链域，以后每增加一个节点，都增加了一个空链域)

二叉树的遍历

先，中，后表示根节点是什么时候访问的。无论哪一种遍历方式，都是先左后右的。

先序遍历(PreOrder)

操作过程：

  1. 访问根节点
  2. 先序遍历左子树
  3. 先序遍历右子树

中序遍历(InOrder)

左根右

后序遍历(PostOrder)

左右根

层序遍历(LevelOrder)

需要借助一个队列。从根节点开始，根节点入队，再出队。下一层，左子节点入队，右子节点入队。左子节点出队，左子节点的子节点入队，右子节点的子节点入队。以此类推。

实际效果就是从根到下一层一层的从左到右遍历。

由遍历序列构造二叉树

由先序遍历序列和中序遍历序列可以唯一确定一棵二叉树。后序和中序，层序和中序也可以。
由先序和后序可以确定节点的祖先关系：当先序序列为XY，后序序列为YX时，X是Y的祖先。

PreOrder: 1, 2, 4, 3, 5, 7, 8, 6
InOrder: 2, 4, 1, 7, 5, 8, 3, 6
PostOrder: 4, 2, 7, 8, 5, 6, 3, 1

由PreOrder: 1, 2, 4, 3, 5, 7, 8, 6 可知，根节点为1
由InOrder: 2, 4, 1, 7, 5, 8, 3, 6 可知，根节点的左子树共有2个节点[2,4],右子树有5个节点[7,5,8,3,6]。
再由PreOrder: [2,4]和[3,5,7,8,6]可知，根节点的左子节点为2，右子节点为3。
如此递归下去，便能唯一确定这颗二叉树。

线索二叉树

遍历二叉树实质上将非线性结构转化成了线性结构。根据二叉树的性质可知，对于n个节点的二叉树，一定有n+1个空域，可以用没用到的指针指向其前驱或后继节点，以加快访问节点前驱和后继的速度。方便某些二叉树操作算法。

通常规定：若无左子树，令lchild指向其前驱节点；若无右子树，令rchild指向其后继节点。为了表明指针指向的是子节点还是前驱/后继节点。需要增加两个标志域。

通常中序遍历建立的二叉树节点中包含了其前驱后继信息。而先序和后序n2n_2n2​节点的左右子节点不一定是其前驱或后继。

中序遍历建立线索二叉树

中序线索二叉树的遍历

例题

例题1

二叉树的带权路径长度(WPL)为二叉树中所有叶节点的带权路径长度之和。此处叶节点的WPL为业节点的深度乘以权重。设计求树的WPL的算法。

树和森林

树的存储结构

双亲表示法

顺序存储+伪指针。每个节点都保存其唯一的父节点的位置。可以很快找到每个节点的父节点，但求子节点的时候要遍历整个结构。

孩子表示法

将每个节点的子节点都用单链表连起来，n个节点就有n个子链表，叶节点的子链表为空。找子节点方便，找父节点难。

孩子兄弟表示法(二叉树表示法)

二叉链表。每个节点包括：节点值，指向节点第一个子节点的指针，指向节点下一个兄弟节点的指针。

容易找子节点，父节点难找(可以添加指向父节点的指针)。并且可以方便的实现树转换成二叉树的操作。

树，森林和二叉树的转换

树和二叉树都可以用双向链表表示。树节点的两个指针，一个指向第一个子节点，一个指向下一个兄弟节点。二叉树的两个指针，一个指向左子节点，一个指向右子节点。

将树转成二叉树，只要将树的子节点指针变成二叉树的左指针，树的兄弟节点指针变成二叉树的右指针即可。“左孩子，右兄弟”。

二叉树转成树，只要将左指针变成树的子指针，左指针的右子孙全部变成左指针的兄弟指针即可。

森林转换为二叉树：先将森林中的每棵树转换成二叉树，再将第一棵树的根作为总二叉树的根，第一棵树的左子树就成为总二叉树的左子树，将第二棵树作为总二叉树的右子树，再将第三棵树作为总二叉树根的右子树的右子树，以此类推。

二叉树转换为森林：去掉右子树，就得到一棵转换过的二叉树。再去一棵，得到另一棵。直到一棵没有右子树的树为止。二叉树转换为森林，树是唯一的

树和森林的遍历

树 森林 二叉树
先根遍历 先序遍历 先序遍历
后根遍历 中序遍历 中序遍历

应用

二叉排序树(BST)

比父节点小的key都出现在左子树，比父节点大的key都出现在右子树。中序遍历可以得到一个递增的有序序列。
注意：插入顺序不同，生成的BST也不同。

  • 查找：从根节点开始，key比根小则向左查找，否则向右查找。
  • 插入：如果是空树，直接插，如果已存在，不插，如果key比根小则插入左子树，key比根大则插入右子树
  • 删除：删除时需要保持BST的性质
    • 如果删除的是叶节点，直接删除
    • 如果是只有一个子节点的节点，则用其子节点替代。
    • 如果是有两个子节点的节点z，则先找到其直接后继s(右子树的最左子节点)，将其后继的key(和值)赋给z，再删除s(删除必是前两种情况之一)。

查找效率分析，平均查找长度ASL=(节点深度×该层节点数)/总节点数ASL=(\text{节点深度} \times \text{该层节点数}) / \text{总节点数}ASL=(节点深度×该层节点数)/总节点数。易知，二叉排序树的查找长度主要取决于树的高度。

平衡二叉树

又称AVL树(以发明者Adelson-Velsky and Landis名称简写命名)，是一个自平衡的BST树。即每个节点的左右子树的高度差不超过1。在AVL树中，每个节点都有一个平衡因子(Balancefactor=heightOfLeftSubtree−heightOfRightSubtreeBalance factor = heightOfLeftSubtree - heightOfRightSubtreeBalancefactor=heightOfLeftSubtree−heightOfRightSubtree)域。树的每一个节点平衡因子都在[-1,1]之间，则称该树是平衡的。对节点来说，平衡因子大于0，称为左重，小于0称为右重，等于0称为平衡。

插入

每当AVL树插入新节点时，如果没有导致不平衡，则更新路径上节点的平衡因子，到根节点或使某个节点平衡因子变成0为止。如果导致了不平衡，则需要重新平衡。

重新平衡

左旋：将A的左子节点B作为新的根，而A变成B的右子节点。如果B原来有右子节点，则将其变成A的左子节点。
右旋：将A的右子节点B作为新的根，而A变成B的左子节点。如果B原来有左子节点，则将其变成A的右子节点。
注意：A节点代表AVL树中从插入节点开始，向上更新平衡因子时，遇到的第一个平衡因子不在[-1,1]之间的节点。

插入新节点后有四种可能的不平衡情况

  1. LL(在当前根节点左孩子的左子树上插入新节点) – 左重 – 一次右旋
  2. RR(在当前根节点右孩子的右子树上插入新节点) – 右重 – 一次左旋
  3. LR(在当前根节点左孩子的右子树上插入新节点) – 根左重，左孩子右重 – 左孩子一次左旋，根一次右旋
  4. RL(在当前根节点右孩子的左子树上插入新节点) – 根右重，右孩子左重 – 右孩子一次右旋，根一次左旋

总之，右重则左旋，左重则右旋。

python实现插入

复杂度

插入和查找都是O(logn)O(log_n)O(logn​)

哈夫曼树

定义

在实际应用中，树中节点常常被赋予一个表示实际意义的数值，称为该节点的权。从树的根节点到任意节点的路径长度与节点权的乘积称为该节点的带权路径长度。树中所有叶节点的带权路径长度之和称为该树的带权路径长度，记为:

WPL=∑i=1nwiliwi:第i个节点的权重,li:路径长度WPL=\sum_{i=1}^nw_il_i \quad w_i\text{:第i个节点的权重,}l_i\text{:路径长度} WPL=i=1∑n​wi​li​wi​:第i个节点的权重,li​:路径长度

在含n个带权叶子节点 的*二叉树中，其中WPL最小的二叉树称为哈夫曼树，也称最优二叉树。

哈夫曼树的构造

给定n个权值分别为w1w_1w1​,w2w_2w2​,…,wnw_nwn​的节点，通过哈夫曼算法可以构造出最优二叉树，算法描述如下：

  1. 将n个节点分别作为n棵仅含一个节点的二叉树，构成森林F
  2. 从F中取节点权值最小的两个树作为新节点的左右子树，并将新节点的权值设为两课子树的权值之和
  3. 删除F中刚刚选择的两棵子树，同时将得到的新子树加入F
  4. 重复2，3知道F中只剩下一棵树为止

可以看出，哈夫曼树具有如下特性：

  • 每个初始节点最后都成为叶节点，且权值越小的节点到根节点的路径长度越大
  • 构造过程中总共新建了n-1个新节点
  • 每次构造都选择2棵树作为新节点的孩子，因此哈夫曼树中不存在度为1的节点

哈夫曼编码

  • 固定长度编码：对于一个待处理的字符串序列，若对每个字符用同样长度的二进制位表示，则称这种编码方式为固定长度编码。
  • 可变长度编码：给出现频率高的字符以短编码，频率低的字符以长一些的编码，从而减少平均编码长度。
  • 哈夫曼编码：将每个字符当作一个独立的节点，其权值设为其出现频率，构造出哈夫曼树。字符编码即为从根到该字符的路径上边标记的序列，其中0表示转向左子节点，1表示转向右子节点。

entry.title: 队列笔记
entry.content:
定义

队列(Queue)。又称先进先出(FIFO)线性表，也是一种受限线性表。只允许在表的一端插入，另一端删除。

  • 队首(Front)：允许删除的一端。
  • 队尾(Rear)：允许插入的一端。

基本操作：

  • 入队(Enque)：向队尾插入一个新元素
  • 出队(Deque)：从队首删除一个元素
  • 读取头元素(GetHead)：获取队首元素，但不删除

顺序队列

普通队列

  • 初始状态：front == rear == 0
  • 入队：队不满时，先给队尾元素赋值，再将rear加1
  • 出队：队不空时，先将队首元素取出，再将front加1

缺陷：空间利用不充分，可入队的元素是固定的，即表长。超过就会溢出。但如果有元素出队，数组前面空出的部分就浪费了。

循环队列

为了解决以上假溢出的情况，可将队列从逻辑上视为一个环，每当该溢出时，指针自动回到0。

  • 初始状态：front == rear == 0
  • 入队：rear = (rear + 1) % MAXSIZE
  • 出队：front = (front + 1) % MAXSIZE
  • 队长：(rear + MAXSIZE - front) % MAXSIZE
  • 队满：front = rear?要区分
    • 空一个位置出来，即队首指针在队尾指针的下一位置作为队满的标志。
    • 在类型中加一个数据成员size。
    • 类型中加一个数据成员tag。删除时设tag=0,则front == rear且tag == 0时则为队空。插入时设tag=1，则front == rear且tag == 1则为队满。

链式队列

双端队列

两端都可以插入删除的队列。

  • 输入受限的双端队列：只允许在一端进行插入删除，另一端只能删除
  • 输出受限的双端队列：只允许在一端进行插入删除，另一端只能插入

设输入序列为1,2,3,4
(1)由输入受限队列得不到的输出序列
(2)由输出受限队列得不到的输出序列
(3)两个都得不到的输出序列

令输入受限队列仅end1可输入，输出受限队列仅end2可输出。
对输入受限队列：
若仅从end1输出，则相当于队列。则由Catalan公式知有14种输出序列。
因为输入受限，
当输入序列只有3个元素时：输出序列只有6个，Catalan数为5，得不到的输出序列为312，借助end2，可以得到。
当输入序列有4个元素时：如果第一个元素不为4，则4插在后3个数中间或最后都是可行的。如果第一个元素为4，则序列中必定剩下321或123，无论从哪一段端出，都不可能输出2。
所以，输入受限队列得不到的输出序列为4213和4231。

对输出受限队列：
同理。如果输出的第一个元素为4，则1,2,3必定都已经输入了。无论从哪一端输入，1和2必定是相邻的。所以，输出受限队列得不到的输出序列为4132和4231。
